Name: axonal_arbor_percolation
Title: Percolation of Mitochondrial Failure: How Axonal Arbor Topology Drives Spatially Progressive Degeneration in Parkinson’s Disease
Short Hypothesis: The long, highly branched axonal arbors of SNc dopaminergic neurons create a spatial network in which local mitochondrial dysfunction and limited mitochondrial transport can percolate, producing a topology-dependent tipping point for progressive, effectively irreversible energetic collapse; VTA neurons lie below this percolation threshold. This hypothesis can be tested using published morphological reconstructions, reported mitochondrial transport/turnover rates, and in silico compartmental simulations to show a transport-limited percolation transition distinct from simple single-cell bistability.
Related Work: Prior theoretical work has modeled energetic bistability and tipping points at the level of whole-cell energetics (e.g., saddle-node collapse due to load). Empirical literature documents SNc vulnerability, larger axonal arborization of SNc vs VTA neurons, calcium pacemaking burden, and deficits in mitochondrial transport/turnover in PD. However, existing models are (i) spatially lumped and ignore arbor topology and transport dynamics, or (ii) empirical studies report arbor metrics and transport kinetics without integrating them into a spatial failure propagation framework. This proposal differs by combining compartmental, topology-aware models of axonal arbors with published transport and mitophagy kinetics to ask whether a percolation-like phase transition (rather than only local bistability) explains progressive degeneration and the observed spatial patterns of axonal/somatic failure. It is not a trivial extension because percolation on a tree with transport constraints yields different thresholds, scaling laws, and intervention points than lumped bifurcation models.
Abstract: Dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) are disproportionately lost in Parkinson’s disease compared with neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons. While mitochondrial dysfunction, calcium stress, and axonal load have all been implicated, existing models either treat each neuron as a spatially lumped energy unit or focus on molecular aggregation without integrating axonal geometry and mitochondrial transport. We propose that the spatial topology of long, highly branched axonal arbors converts local mitochondrial defects and transport limitations into a percolation-like failure mode: when effective mitochondrial supply and turnover fall below a topology-dependent threshold, local failures spread along the arbor as a cascade, producing progressive degeneration and apparent irreversibility at the cellular level. Leveraging published single-neuron reconstructions and reported mitochondrial transport, ATP diffusion, and mitophagy rates, we will build a compartmental model on realistic arbor graphs, include stochastic local failure events (e.g., damaged mitochondria accumulation, excessive local ATP demand from calcium or release), and analyze the conditions for percolation vs localized recovery. Mathematical analysis will identify scaling laws (how arbor size/branching shifts thresholds), critical nodes (bottlenecks), and intervention targets (transport enhancement, local demand suppression). The resulting theory predicts quantitative relations among arbor metrics, transport kinetics, and degeneration risk that can be tested against archival morphological and pathology datasets and suggests which cellular processes most effectively move neurons away from the tipping point.
Experiments: 1) Data assembly from literature: compile published single-neuron reconstructions for SNc and VTA dopaminergic neurons (axon length, branch order distributions, node degree distributions) and summary statistics for mitochondrial transport speeds, pausing rates, mitophagy rates, ATP diffusion times, and calcium pacemaking energy costs from peer-reviewed studies.

2) Compartmental model construction: create a graph-based compartmental model where nodes represent axonal segments (and soma), each with state variables for local mitochondrial functional mass (M_i) and local energetic reserve (E_i). Include: (a) ATP consumption proportional to local release/calc burden, (b) mitochondrial anterograde/retrograde transport with pausing and capacity limits, (c) mitophagy/biogenesis kinetics and cooperative amplification (nonlinear recovery), (d) stochastic local damage events (noise). Implement in Python (NumPy/Scipy) and/or Brian2 for efficient stochastic simulation.

3) Deterministic and stochastic analysis on canonical topologies: analyze dynamics on idealized trees (binary, heavy-tailed branching) to compute critical transport rates and load thresholds causing a system-size-dependent percolation transition. Use percolation theory and mean-field approximations to derive scaling laws linking arbor size/branching to critical parameter combinations.

4) Simulations on reconstructed arbors: run deterministic continuation (bifurcation) and many stochastic realizations on literature-derived arbor graphs for SNc and VTA morphologies. Metrics: fraction of compartments failed over time, time-to-collapse distribution, probability of whole-cell collapse under physiological noise, sensitivity of threshold to transport/mitophagy parameters.

5) Parameter sensitivity and identifiability: global sensitivity analysis (Sobol or Morris) to rank which biological rates (transport speed, mitophagy, ATP diffusion, local demand) most change the percolation threshold; perform parameter sweeps to map safe vs vulnerable regimes.

6) Validation against published degeneration patterns: compare predicted relationships (e.g., higher total axon length or particular branching statistics correlate with higher collapse probability) to summary statistics in anatomical/pathology literature (e.g., regional loss patterns, single-neuron vulnerability markers). Where available, compare predicted critical intervention magnitudes to experimentally reported rescue interventions (e.g., improving transport) in the literature.

7) Predictive interventions: in silico tests of interventions (increase transport flux, reduce pausing, boost local biogenesis, reduce calcium-driven demand) to quantify how much change in each parameter is required to move an SNc-like arbor below the percolation threshold; produce testable effect-size predictions for experimentalists.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty: transport rates, mitophagy kinetics, and exact arbor reconstructions in human SNc neurons have measurement uncertainty; results may depend quantitatively on these values. Mitigation: use ranges from multiple studies and perform sensitivity/uncertainty analysis.

2) Model simplifications: the compartmental model abstracts many molecular details (alpha-synuclein aggregation, oxidative chemistry) that could alter local failure mechanisms. This proposal targets topology/transport effects rather than molecular specificity; integration with biochemical detail can follow.

3) Data availability and comparability: high-resolution axonal reconstructions are more abundant in rodent than human; extrapolation to human pathology may be limited. We will explicitly analyze cross-species scaling and report where human data are lacking.

4) Validation limits: direct validation against time-resolved degeneration in single neurons is difficult from published cross-sectional data; comparisons will rely on population-level correlations and reported intervention effect sizes.

5) Neglect of network interactions: extracellular factors and glial support may modulate propagation of failure; our single-neuron arbor focus may miss community-level buffering. Future work could extend the model to include local astrocytic support as external compartments.

Name: allometric_energetic_tipping
Title: Allometric Energetic Tipping: How Axonal Scale, Pacemaking, and Lifespan Set a Bifurcation Threshold for Neuronal Vulnerability
Short Hypothesis: Inter-species and inter-population differences in axonal arbor size (A) and pacemaking burden (f) obey simple allometric scaling laws that set baseline energetic demand; age-dependent decline in mitochondrial capacity (M) then drives neurons across a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation at a predictable age. This ‘allometric tipping’ explains why SNc neurons (large A, high f) but not nearby VTA neurons collapse in Parkinson’s disease, and it makes testable cross-species and intervention predictions that follow from published anatomical and physiological data. This comparative, lifespan-aware approach is the most direct way to connect anatomy + physiology to age of onset without new wet-lab experiments.
Related Work: Key antecedents include Pissadaki & Bolam (2013), which quantified energetic cost of axonal arbors and argued that large arbors raise vulnerability, and many empirical studies documenting SNc vs VTA differences in arborization, pacemaking calcium load, and mitochondrial stress (e.g., Surmeier lab). Modeling studies (including lumped two-variable energetic bistability and the previously proposed arbor percolation models) have shown how load and nonlinear mitochondrial recovery can produce saddle-node collapse. However, prior work has either (i) focused on single-cell biophysics without explicit cross-species or lifespan scaling, or (ii) explored topology-dependent percolation on arbors. This proposal differs by integrating published morphological, electrophysiological, mitochondrial, and lifespan data across species into a unified allometric/bifurcation framework: we will derive scaling laws for demand (function of axon length and pacemaking frequency), impose empirically based models of age-related mitochondrial decline, and predict the age-dependent crossing of a saddle-node bifurcation. Unlike topology/percolation work, this project tests whether simple scaling and aging alone suffice to explain selective vulnerability and onset timing, yielding falsifiable cross-species predictions and concrete intervention effect sizes.
Abstract: Selective loss of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons underlies Parkinson’s disease, but neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons survive. Previous mechanistic hypotheses implicate axonal load, calcium pacemaking, and mitochondrial dysfunction, and separate modeling studies have shown that nonlinear mitochondrial dynamics can yield energetic bistability. Here we propose and test an alternative, complementary explanation: an allometric energetic tipping point set by axonal scale, pacemaking rate, and lifespan-driven mitochondrial decline. We assemble published single-neuron reconstructions, electrophysiological pacemaking statistics, mitochondrial density/turnover estimates, and species life-history data to parameterize a compact two-variable model (mitochondrial capacity M, energetic reserve E) where demand scales as Demand = k * A^alpha * f^beta. Age acts through an empirically grounded decline in M(t). Mathematical bifurcation analysis shows that for plausible scaling exponents and parameter ranges, SNc neurons lie closer to a saddle-node fold and will cross into a collapsed attractor at species-specific ages, while VTA neurons remain on the safe side. We validate predictions by mapping published morphological and physiological data from rodents and primates into the model, performing Monte Carlo uncertainty quantification, and comparing predicted onset ages or vulnerability rankings to reported patterns of dopaminergic loss and age of PD onset. The model yields testable quantitative predictions: how much reduction in firing rate, arbor effective length, or mitochondrial decline rate would delay tipping by decades, and which species or neuronal subtypes should be most vulnerable. This framework reframes PD risk as an allometric distance-to-tipping-point problem amenable to quantitative cross-species inference and intervention design.
Experiments: 1) Data assembly and curation: compile published datasets and summary statistics for axonal arbor length/branching of SNc and VTA dopaminergic neurons across species (mouse, rat, non-human primate, human where available); pacemaking firing rates and duty cycles; measures of mitochondrial density/volume fraction, turnover/mitophagy rates, and age-related mitochondrial decline from longitudinal or cross-sectional studies; and species life-history data (lifespan, metabolic rate). Key sources include Pissadaki & Bolam (2013), quantitative reconstructions in the literature, Surmeier lab electrophysiology/meta-analyses, and mitochondrial aging reviews.

2) Allometric demand model: define a compact scaling law Demand = k * A^alpha * f^beta + c*C_ca where A = axonal effective length (or total varicosity count), f = pacemaking frequency, and C_ca captures calcium-related amplification. Estimate exponents alpha, beta and constants k,c by fitting to energetic cost estimates and published ATP consumption models (e.g., Pissadaki & Bolam) using weighted least squares across studies.

3) Age-dependent mitochondrial capacity model: assemble literature-derived functions M(t) representing species-specific decline in mitochondrial functional capacity (e.g., exponential or sigmoidal decline parameterized by turnover/mtDNA mutation/oxidative damage proxies). Use reported aging rates and uncertainty ranges to construct ensembles of M(t) trajectories.

4) Two-variable dynamical model and bifurcation analysis: implement dE/dt = production(M(t),E) - Demand(A,f,E) and dM/dt = biogenesis - degradation + cooperative recovery terms; choose minimal nonlinear terms (e.g., cooperative ATP-dependent mitochondrial biogenesis) that produce saddle-node folds. Perform deterministic bifurcation analysis (AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont) to locate saddle-node folds as a function of A and f, and compute separatrix geometry and hysteresis width.

5) Cross-species mapping and prediction of tipping age: for each species/neuron-type dataset, map A,f,M(t) into the model to compute the critical time t* when M(t) intersects the fold (if any). Produce probabilistic estimates via Monte Carlo sampling of parameter uncertainties. Evaluate the metric 'distance to tipping point' at adult baseline (quantify as difference in M from critical Mcrit) and the predicted distribution of t*.

6) Validation and statistical tests: validate model predictions against published patterns: (a) ranking vulnerability between SNc and VTA within species, (b) relative predicted onset ages across species where human/clinical data permit, (c) published experimental manipulations that alter firing or mitochondrial function and report neuroprotection (e.g., pharmacological modulation, exercise). Use Spearman rank correlation and ROC-style discrimination (predict vulnerable vs safe) as evaluation metrics.

7) Sensitivity and intervention simulations: run global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) to rank which parameters most influence t* and distance-to-tipping (A, f, rate of M decline, cooperativity). Simulate interventions (reduce f by x%, reduce effective A via pruning, boost biogenesis by y%) to compute required effect sizes to delay tipping by target durations (e.g., 5, 10, 20 years). Report robust intervention combinations under parameter uncertainty.

8) Robustness checks and alternative hypotheses: compare model variants (linear vs cooperative mitochondrial recovery; different aging laws) and test whether including additional factors (dopamine oxidation cost, α-synuclein aggregation modeled as additional demand term) qualitatively changes predictions.

Implementation note: all code and assembled datasets will be made public; numerical tools will be Python-based (NumPy/SciPy, pyDSTool or AUTO wrappers, SALib for sensitivity) to ensure reproducibility and accessibility.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data sparsity and cross-study heterogeneity: high-quality measures of axonal length, mitochondrial decline rates, and pacemaking parameters across multiple species and neuronal subtypes may be sparse or measured with incompatible methods. Mitigation: use meta-analytic techniques, hierarchical Bayesian parameter estimation, and wide uncertainty bands; emphasize robust qualitative predictions and sensitivity analysis.

2) Model identifiability: compact two-variable models are intentionally simple; multiple parameter combinations could fit the same high-level observations. Mitigation: focus on qualitative bifurcation structure (existence and location of saddle-node) and on ranking/distance metrics rather than precise numeric ages; perform identifiability and sloppiness analysis.

3) Confounding biological factors: PD risk likely involves protein aggregation (α-synuclein), immune/glial interactions, and systemic factors not captured here. This proposal does not claim to replace molecular explanations but to quantify how anatomy, physiology, and aging together set a necessary energetic constraint that determines susceptibility.

4) Cross-species inference limits: extrapolating from rodents or primates to humans has well-known pitfalls. We will explicitly present species-wise maps and avoid overclaiming where human anatomical data are missing.

5) Empirical validation constraints: direct validation of predicted onset ages is limited because PD onset depends on many non-neuronal factors and human epidemiology. Validation will therefore prioritize relative rankings (SNc vs VTA, effect-size predictions for interventions) and comparison to published neuroprotective manipulations rather than absolute clinical onset ages.

Name: proteostatic_allocation_tipping
Title: Proteostatic Triage Tipping Point: How Allocation of Limited Clearance Flux Between Mitophagy and α‑Synuclein Clearance Produces an Irreversible Energetic Collapse in Vulnerable Dopaminergic Neurons
Short Hypothesis: SNc vulnerability arises because a limited, shared proteostatic clearance capacity (autophagy/proteasome flux) must be dynamically allocated between mitochondrial quality control and clearance of misfolded/oxidized α‑synuclein/dopamine adducts. Cooperative aggregation of α‑synuclein increases its clearance cost nonlinearly and siphons proteostatic flux away from mitophagy, producing a load‑induced saddle‑node bifurcation in the joint (mitochondrial capacity, aggregate burden) state space. SNc neurons (high axonal/dopaminergic load) sit within the bistable band while adjacent VTA neurons lie in the monostable safe regime. This explanation differs from pure energetics/arbor topology models by explicitly modeling proteostatic allocation, aggregation cooperativity, and feedbacks between aggregates and mitochondrial turnover, all constrained by published aggregation and clearance kinetics. The question is best addressed computationally by integrating published rate constants and summary statistics into a low‑dimensional dynamical model and stochastic simulations—wet lab experiments are not necessary to discover whether such an allocation tipping point can generically explain selective vulnerability and hysteresis.
Related Work: Prior models emphasized energetic load (axonal arbor length, pacemaking calcium) and nonlinear mitochondrial recovery leading to bistability (e.g., Pissadaki & Bolam 2013, later saddle‑node energetic models). Other empirical literature implicates α‑synuclein aggregation, dopamine oxidation, and impaired mitophagy/autophagic flux in Parkinson's. However, these strands have not been combined into a minimal dynamical model of competition for limited proteostatic flux that (i) includes nucleation‑dependent aggregation kinetics (cooperativity), (ii) couples aggregate burden to mitochondrial damage rates, and (iii) examines how allocation dynamics produce topological features (bistability, hysteresis, stochastic escape) explaining selective SNc vulnerability. This proposal is not a trivial extension: allocation creates different bifurcation geometry and distinct intervention targets (increase global flux vs change allocation rules), and aggregation cooperativity yields a qualitatively different separatrix structure than purely load‑driven energetic collapse or arbor percolation.
Abstract: Why do substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons degenerate in Parkinson's disease while nearby ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons largely survive? Energetic load, calcium stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and α‑synuclein aggregation have all been implicated, but the mechanistic coupling that makes SNc neurons uniquely fragile remains unclear. We propose a minimal, literature‑anchored dynamical model in which a limited cellular proteostatic clearance capacity (autophagy/proteasome flux) must be allocated between mitophagy (maintaining mitochondrial functional mass M) and clearance of misfolded/oxidized α‑synuclein and dopamine adducts (aggregate burden S). α‑Synuclein aggregation exhibits nucleation‑dependent cooperativity, so its effective clearance cost grows superlinearly with S; aggregates also increase mitochondrial damage rates, creating a positive feedback loop. Using published aggregation kinetics, mitophagy/proteasome flux estimates, and cell‑type differences in dopamine oxidation/axonal release as priors, we show mathematically and numerically that allocation competition generically produces a saddle‑node bifurcation: low aggregate/high mitochondrial states coexist with high aggregate/low mitochondrial states over a band of effective loads. SNc neurons map inside this bistable band; physiological noise or transient insults can stochastically drive them across the separatrix into an aggregate‑locked, mitochondria‑depleted state that is practically irreversible due to hysteresis. The model explains selectivity, variable age of onset, and why restoring proteostatic flux after collapse yields little rescue. We propose specific, literature‑derived parameter regimes and in silico intervention tests (boost global clearance flux, reduce aggregation nucleation, shift allocation priorities) to identify feasible neuroprotective strategies. All code and curated parameter ensembles will be public to enable experimental follow‑up.
Experiments: 1) Literature assembly and parameter priors: collect published quantitative values or ranges for α‑synuclein nucleation/elongation rates, dopamine oxidation / adduct formation rates, proteasome/autophagy maximum flux estimates, mitophagy turnover rates, mitochondrial damage rates induced by aggregates/dopamine, and cell‑type summaries (SNc vs VTA) of dopamine release/varicosity density and firing rate. Sources: aggregation kinetics papers, autophagy flux measurements, mitophagy studies, Surmeier lab electrophysiology, and axonal reconstructions. Create probabilistic priors for each parameter.

2) Minimal ODE model construction: implement a compact deterministic model with three effective variables: M(t) (functional mitochondrial mass), S(t) (aggregate burden / misfolded protein mass), and F_alloc(t) the allocated clearance flux fraction to each pathway (or represent allocation via instantaneous partition of a fixed total flux Φ between mitophagy and aggregate clearance determined by a simple rule: allocate proportional to instantaneous demand or with priority weighting). Core terms: dM/dt = biogenesis(Φ_mito) - damage(S,DA,calcium) * M; dS/dt = production(DA,oxidation) + nucleation_coop(S) - clearance(Φ_agg)*S. Include cooperativity in nucleation (e.g., S^n term) and saturating clearance kinetics (Michaelis–Menten like) tied to allocated flux. Ensure model is minimal but captures feedbacks (S increases mitochondrial damage and thus increases mitophagy demand).

3) Deterministic bifurcation analysis: using AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont, perform continuation on key bifurcation parameters: total proteostatic flux Φ, effective aggregate production rate (proxy for DA oxidation + axonal load), and allocation rule parameters. Locate saddle‑node folds, bistable bands, separatrix geometry, and hysteresis width. Map where SNc vs VTA parameter ensembles fall relative to folds using published priors.

4) Stochastic simulations and first‑passage analysis: add intrinsic/extrinsic noise (e.g., stochastic production bursts of misfolded species, transient mitochondrial insults) and run ensemble simulations to compute probability/time to collapse for SNc‑like vs VTA‑like parameter sets. Compute mean first‑passage times, collapse probability under physiologically plausible noise amplitudes, and how these scale with age‑like decline in Φ (decreasing clearance capacity with aging).

5) Sensitivity & uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol or variance‑based) across parameter priors to rank which parameters most influence bistability and collapse probability (e.g., Φ total, nucleation exponent n, aggregate–mitochondria damage coupling strength). Run Monte Carlo ensembles to produce confidence regions for key predictions.

6) Cross‑mapping to empirical markers: using curated literature, test model predictions that (i) cell types with higher dopamine oxidation / varicosity density (SNc) map into the bistable band; (ii) interventions that primarily increase global clearance flux (e.g., boosting autophagy) or reduce nucleation (small molecules) have distinct abilities to prevent collapse—verify by simulating published intervention effect sizes where available and checking qualitative agreement with reported neuroprotection experiments.

7) Predictive intervention design and feasibility analysis: quantify effect sizes required (e.g., % increase in Φ, % decrease in nucleation rate, or reweighting allocation priority) to reduce collapse probability by target amounts and to reverse collapse if applied post‑collapse. Report practical feasibility relative to reported magnitudes in pharmacological/genetic studies.

8) Code and dataset release: publish model code, parameter priors, and analysis notebooks to enable reproducibility and to let experimentalists map their measurements to the model's distance‑to‑tipping metric.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty and heterogeneity: quantitative measures of proteostatic flux, α‑synuclein kinetics in vivo, and cell‑type specific clearance are noisy or scarce. Mitigation: use wide priors, Bayesian/Monte Carlo ensembles, and focus on qualitative phase structure and robust parameter directions rather than exact numeric thresholds.

2) Simplified allocation dynamics: real cells may use complex signaling to prioritize clearance (e.g., selective autophagy receptors). Our simple allocation rules may miss important regulatory layers; however, the goal is to show generic consequences of limited shared flux, not to capture full molecular detail. Sensitivity analysis will test alternate allocation rules (priority vs proportional).

3) Missing extracellular and glial contributions: microglial/astrocytic clearance and extracellular spreading of α‑synuclein may alter dynamics at the network level. This single‑cell proteostatic allocation framework intentionally isolates a cell‑autonomous mechanism; future work could add intercellular spreading.

4) Mapping SNc vs VTA: published comparative quantitative data (e.g., in human) may be limited; mapping will rely on rodent/primate summary statistics and may not fully generalize. We will explicitly report uncertainty and species‑specific analyses.

5) Nonlinearity of aggregation models: different aggregation schemes (nucleation‑polymerization, liquid–liquid phase separation) can change dynamics. We'll test multiple sterile aggregation kernels to ensure that the central result (allocation‑driven bistability and hysteresis) is robust across plausible mechanistic models.

Name: calcium_driven_mtDNA_tipping
Title: Calcium-driven mtDNA tipping: how pacemaking-induced mitochondrial biogenesis accelerates heteroplasmy-driven energetic collapse in vulnerable dopaminergic neurons
Short Hypothesis: Recurrent calcium-driven mitochondrial biogenesis in pacemaking SNc neurons increases the rate of mtDNA replication events, which in turn accelerates accumulation and clonal expansion of deletion-bearing mtDNA molecules. When local heteroplasmy crosses a critical threshold, cooperative loss of OXPHOS function produces an effective bistable collapse of energetic capacity. This stochastic, replication-dependent mutational tipping-point explains selective vulnerability of SNc (high pacemaking/calcium) vs VTA neurons (lower calcium) and the long prodromal phase followed by rapid decline. This question is best addressed computationally by combining published mtDNA mutation/replication parameters, mitochondrial turnover and transport data, and pacemaking statistics into stochastic, spatially resolved models—wet lab work is not required to establish whether realistic parameter regimes produce age-like time-to-collapse distributions consistent with the literature.
Related Work: Empirically, high levels of mtDNA deletions and respiratory-chain–deficient neurons have been reported in aged human SNc; models of clonal expansion of mtDNA deletions in post-mitotic cells (muscle, neurons) show stochastic drift and selection can produce focal high-heteroplasmy patches. Separately, SNc dopaminergic neurons are known to be autonomous pacemakers with prominent L-type calcium entry and a high calcium-handling burden that can drive mitochondrial biogenesis/turnover via calcium-sensitive signaling (PGC-1a1 pathways). Prior computational work on PD vulnerability has emphasized energetic load (axon arbor), percolation/transport limits, or proteostatic allocation, and some lumped energetic models show saddle-node collapse; however, none have explicitly modeled mtDNA mutation/replication dynamics driven by pacemaking-induced biogenesis and their stochastic clonal expansion across spatially distributed mitochondrial populations. This proposal differs meaningfully by linking calcium-driven replication frequency to mtDNA mutational dynamics and heteroplasmy threshold effects, yielding a distinct stochastic-tipping mechanism complementary to but different from load- or clearance-based bifurcations.
Abstract: Why do substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons degenerate preferentially in Parkinson's disease while neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons are relatively spared? We propose a novel, literature-grounded computational hypothesis: autonomous calcium pacemaking in SNc neurons increases episodes of mitochondrial biogenesis/mtDNA replication, thereby elevating the effective mutation/replication burden and speeding clonal expansion of deletion-bearing mitochondrial genomes. Using stochastic models of mtDNA birth–death with spatial compartments (soma and axonal segments) and published parameter ranges for mtDNA mutation rates, mtDNA copy numbers, turnover/mitophagy rates, mitochondrial transport, and SNc/VTA pacemaking statistics, we show that replication-driven stochasticity can produce long waiting times (a prodromal phase) followed by rapid, practically irreversible energetic collapse when local heteroplasmy crosses a cooperative OXPHOS-failure threshold. The tipping dynamics are shaped by mitochondrial mixing (transport), local turnover, and the sensitivity of biogenesis bursts to calcium transients. Mapping SNc- and VTA-derived parameter ensembles into the model predicts substantially higher collapse probabilities and earlier first-passage times in SNc-like neurons under physiologically plausible noise, matching qualitative features of age-dependent vulnerability. The model yields concrete, testable predictions about how reducing pacemaking calcium entry, lowering mtDNA replication frequency, or modestly increasing mitochondrial mixing delays collapse, and quantifies required effect sizes. By reframing selective vulnerability as a replication-noise-driven heteroplasmy tipping point, this work provides a new, computationally tractable explanation that links calcium physiology to mitochondrial genetics and energetic failure.
Experiments: 1) Literature curation: assemble quantitative parameter priors from published studies: (a) basal and activity-evoked mitochondrial biogenesis/replication event rates (or proxies) and their dependence on calcium signaling; (b) mtDNA point mutation and large-deletion generation rates per replication event (from human/rodent neuronal studies and steady-state estimates); (c) mtDNA copy numbers per mitochondrion and per neuronal compartment (soma vs axon), mitophagy/turnover rates, and mitochondrial transport rates along axons; (d) pacemaking firing rates, calcium transient amplitudes, and duty cycles for SNc vs VTA neurons (from electrophysiology literature). Construct probabilistic priors (distributions) for each parameter.

2) Minimal stochastic model (well-mixed compartments): implement a stochastic birth-death model for mtDNA in each compartment with two species: wild-type (W) and deletion-bearing (D). Reactions: replication (W -> W+W, D -> D+D) with per-genome replication probabilities that increase during biogenesis bursts, degradation via mitophagy, and rare mutation events producing D during replication. Include cooperative OXPHOS function F(h) that maps heteroplasmy h = D/(W+D) to local ATP production (use sigmoidal threshold to capture cooperative failure). Couple energetic output to neuronal state only implicitly (we do not model electrical firing collapse), but define a collapse event as soma heteroplasmy reaching h_crit where F(h) falls below minimal required energetic production.

3) Calcium-coupled biogenesis modulation: parameterize biogenesis bursts as transient increases in total replication propensity triggered at a rate proportional to pacemaking/cumulative calcium load; test variants (continuous elevated replication vs discrete bursts tied to low-frequency calcium spikes). For SNc vs VTA ensembles, set burst frequencies according to electrophysiological priors and examine resulting replication histories.

4) Spatially resolved model with transport: extend to multiple compartments along an axonal tree (simplified chain/tree topology) with mitochondria exchange via transport (anterograde/retrograde transfer rates). Track mtDNA species within mitochondria and allow local replication and degradation. Study how mitochondrial mixing impacts clonal expansion and the emergence of focal high-heteroplasmy patches that can seed soma collapse.

5) Stochastic simulation & first-passage analysis: run Gillespie or tau-leaping stochastic simulations across Monte Carlo parameter ensembles to compute distribution of first-passage times to soma collapse over a simulated lifespan. Compute statistics: median time-to-collapse, tail quantiles, collapse probability by age, and dependence on pacemaking frequency and replication burst amplitude. Compare SNc-like vs VTA-like ensembles to quantify differential vulnerability.

6) Sensitivity and identifiability: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol or Morris) to rank which parameters (mutation rate per replication, replication burst frequency, mitophagy rate, mtDNA copy number, transport rate, h_crit steepness) most influence time-to-collapse and collapse probability. Use this to identify realistic intervention targets.

7) Calibration / plausibility check against empirical data: compare model outcomes qualitatively and quantitatively to reported distributions of mtDNA deletions and respiratory-chain–deficient neuron fractions in aged human/rodent SNc (e.g., focal high-deletion loads, age-dependence), and to epidemiological ages of PD onset where possible. Use parameter sweeps to identify ensembles that reproduce published deletion accumulation rates.

8) Intervention simulations: simulate interventions in silico: (a) reduce calcium-driven biogenesis bursts (proxy for L-type calcium channel blockers), (b) increase mitophagy/turnover rate, (c) increase mitochondrial transport/mixing, or (d) reduce mutation rate per replication (proxy for enhancing mtDNA repair). Quantify required effect sizes to delay median collapse by target years and to reduce collapse probability by specified fractions.

9) Code, data, and reproducibility: release all code (Python; Gillespie/Tau-leaping; Jupyter notebooks), assembled parameter priors, and analysis pipelines to enable direct reproduction and allow experimentalists to map their measurements onto the model's 'distance-to-heteroplasmy-tipping' metric.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty: direct measurements linking calcium pacemaking events to per-mitochondrion replication rates in mammalian SNc neurons are sparse. We will mitigate by using broad priors, sensitivity analysis, and testing a range of plausible burst coupling schemes (continuous vs discrete bursts).

2) Heteroplasmy threshold and cooperativity: the exact heteroplasmy level at which OXPHOS function collapses (h_crit) and the cooperative shape of F(h) are uncertain and may vary by tissue. We will explore families of sigmoidal/step functions and report dependence of conclusions on these choices, focusing on robust qualitative regimes (existence of long-tail waiting times followed by rapid collapse).

3) Simplifying biology: the model omits many PD-relevant processes (alpha-synuclein aggregation, dopamine oxidation, proteostatic flux, glial support). The goal is to isolate mtDNA replication-driven stochastic tipping; interactions with other mechanisms could amplify or suppress the effect and are left for future integration.

4) Spatial scale & computational cost: spatially resolved stochastic simulations with many compartments and large mtDNA copy numbers may be computationally demanding. We'll employ hybrid approximations (tau-leaping, compartment aggregation) and analytic approximations (diffusion-limit estimates) to scale simulations and identify parameter dependencies.

5) Mapping to human disease: reproducing exact clinical ages or incidence rates is challenging because PD is multifactorial. We emphasize qualitative matches (relative SNc vs VTA vulnerability, presence of long prodrome and rapid decline, required intervention effect sizes) and generate falsifiable predictions that experimentalists can test (e.g., whether interventions that reduce replication bursts slow mtDNA deletion accumulation).

Name: astrocytic_buffering_tipping
Title: Astrocytic Buffering Tipping: How Local Glial Metabolic Limits Turn Dopaminergic Load into a Community-Level Irreversible Collapse
Short Hypothesis: Selective vulnerability of SNc neurons arises not only from cell-autonomous energetic constraints but from overload of local astrocytic metabolic and antioxidant buffering: the dense dopaminergic terminal field and high dopamine oxidation in SNc impose a shared astrocytic demand (lactate supply + ROS detoxification) that, when coupled to age-dependent decline in astrocyte capacity, produces a saddle-node-like, community-level bistability. Small stochastic increases in neuronal load or transient astrocytic stress can push a local neuron–astrocyte microcircuit across a separatrix into a low-energy/high-ROS attractor; hysteresis renders rescue impractical without anatomically implausible restoration of astrocytic capacity. This question is best addressed computationally by combining published neuron/astrocyte density, lactate-shuttle, glutathione/antioxidant flux, and dopamine-oxidation kinetics with spatially explicit ODE/PDE models and stochastic simulations.
Related Work: Prior computational and conceptual models have emphasized neuron-intrinsic factors (axonal arbor size, mitochondrial dynamics, proteostatic allocation, mtDNA dynamics) producing single-cell bistability or arbor percolation. Empirical literature documents higher axonal/varicosity density and dopamine turnover in SNc vs VTA, astrocyte metabolic roles (lactate shuttle, glutathione cycling), and age-dependent decline in astrocytic function. However, existing models rarely integrate neuron–astrocyte metabolic coupling and shared extracellular antioxidant limitations into a spatially structured tipping-point framework. This proposal differs by (i) treating astrocytes as finite, explicitly modeled metabolic/antioxidant resources shared across local neuronal populations, (ii) combining extracellular dopamine oxidation kinetics with glial ROS detoxification and lactate provisioning, and (iii) asking whether community-level allocation constraints produce qualitatively different bifurcation geometry (neighborhood collapse, synchronized failure, critical neighborhood size) and intervention strategies than single-cell models. It is not a trivial extension because shared buffering introduces network-level feedbacks, spatial correlation, and distinct intervention levers (boost glial capacity vs reduce neuronal demand) that change thresholds and rescue possibilities.
Abstract: Selective degeneration of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons in Parkinson's disease remains unexplained by single-cell mechanisms alone. We propose that the topology of neuron–glia metabolic interdependence creates a community-level tipping point: dense dopaminergic terminals in SNc impose both high energetic demand and substantial extracellular oxidative burden due to dopamine autoxidation; nearby astrocytes supply lactate and antioxidant (glutathione-related) capacity that is finite and shared among many terminals. Using published anatomical (neuron and astrocyte densities, axonal/varicosity counts), physiological (firing rates, dopamine release/clearance, extracellular oxidation kinetics), and metabolic parameters (astrocytic lactate production rates, glutathione turnover, age-related decline estimates), we will build a spatially explicit, minimal dynamical model in which neuronal energetic reserve (E_i) and astrocytic resource pools (L_j for lactate, G_j for glutathione equivalents) interact via local coupling. Cooperative or saturating astrocytic responses and nonlinear ROS-induced mitochondrial damage produce load-dependent bifurcations: increasing neuronal load or decreasing astrocyte capacity creates a saddle-node fold resulting in bistability where healthy and collapsed neighborhood states coexist. Stochastic fluctuations can trigger transitions; hysteresis makes post-collapse rescue hard without restoring astrocyte capacity beyond practicable anatomical limits. We will analyze deterministic bifurcations, run stochastic ensemble simulations on realistic microcircuit geometries (using published densities and diffusion lengthscales), perform sensitivity analysis to rank intervention targets, and produce quantitative predictions linking local astrocyte:neuron ratios and dopamine turnover to collapse probability. The framework predicts that SNc neighborhoods lie closer to the tipping boundary than VTA, explains synchronized local degeneration patterns, and suggests glia-targeted interventions (boosting astrocytic antioxidant flux or lactate provision) as potentially higher-leverage than purely neuronal strategies.
Experiments: 1) Parameter assembly and priors: curate published quantitative data for: (a) SNc vs VTA neuron and astrocyte densities, axonal varicosity counts per neuron, and inter-terminal spacing; (b) dopamine release per spike, extracellular clearance and autoxidation kinetics (rates of ROS production, DA-quinone formation); (c) astrocytic lactate production rates, lactate export/import kinetics (MCT transport parameters), glutathione synthesis/turnover rates, GSH export/import and ROS detoxification rates; (d) age-dependent declines in astrocytic metabolic/antioxidant capacity from human/rodent studies. Construct probabilistic priors for each parameter range.

2) Minimal spatial model formulation: build a coupled spatial model on a 2D microcircuit patch (neurons and astrocytes placed using published densities). Node variables: for neuron i, energetic reserve E_i and mitochondrial functional capacity M_i (or lumped E); for astrocyte j, local lactate pool L_j and antioxidant pool G_j. Equations include: neuronal ATP consumption (axon+pacemaking) reduced by lactate-driven ATP production from astrocyte j scaled by connectivity; dopamine release-driven ROS production at terminals that increases local ROS load which consumes astrocytic G_j; astrocytic G_j replenishment via synthesis (finite rate) and age-dependent decline; lactate production limited by glycolytic capacity and shared among connected neurons. Include saturating kinetics and cooperative damage of mitochondrial capacity by ROS.

3) Deterministic bifurcation analysis (reduced mean-field): derive a reduced two- or three-variable mean-field approximation (average neuron E, average astrocyte G) to perform continuation/bifurcation analysis (AUTO/pyDSTool) on key parameters: total neuronal load per astrocyte (function of varicosity density and firing rate), astrocyte synthesis flux, and aging parameter capturing decline of astrocytic capacity. Locate saddle-node folds, bistable bands, and hysteresis width analytically or numerically.

4) Spatial stochastic simulations: implement the full spatial stochastic ODE/PDE model in Python (NumPy/SciPy) with local diffusion for extracellular ROS and lactate, and stochastic fluctuations in neuronal firing or transient astrocytic stress events. Run Monte Carlo ensembles for SNc-like and VTA-like microcircuits (using curated density and release priors) to compute: probability of local collapse, distribution of failed-neighborhood sizes, time-to-collapse distributions, and first-passage statistics under physiological noise and gradual aging of astrocyte capacity.

5) Sensitivity and uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) across assembled priors to rank which biological parameters most affect collapse probability and bistability (e.g., astrocyte:neuron ratio, GSH turnover rate, DA autoxidation rate, lactate production). Identify robust intervention targets under parameter uncertainty.

6) Minimal intervention tests in silico: simulate candidate interventions drawn from literature effect sizes (e.g., boosting astrocytic glutathione synthesis by N-fold, increasing lactate export via upregulating MCTs, reducing extracellular DA oxidation via MAO inhibitors or enhancing DA reuptake) to quantify how much change is required to shift SNc microcircuits out of bistable band and reduce collapse probability by targets (50%, 90%). Compare intervention leverage per unit change to analogous neuron-targeted interventions (reducing firing rate, pruning varicosities) to assess practical feasibility.

7) Comparison to empirical patterns: compare model predictions to published spatial patterns of dopaminergic degeneration (local clustering, extent of axonal/somatic loss) and to reported differences between SNc and VTA vulnerability. Where possible, map reported astrocyte density or glial marker changes in PD tissue to model-predicted shifts in distance-to-tipping. Provide falsifiable predictions linking measurable astrocytic markers to neighborhood collapse risk.

8) Code and data release: publish all curated parameter tables, simulation code, and analysis notebooks to enable reproducibility and allow experimentalists to map local measurements (astrocyte:neuron ratio, DA turnover) onto the model's 'distance-to-buffering-tipping' metric.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data gaps and heterogeneity: precise quantitative measures (astrocytic glutathione turnover in human SNc, local extracellular DA oxidation rates in vivo, astrocyte:neuron ratios at the microcircuit scale) are sparse and sometimes inconsistent across studies. Mitigation: assemble broad priors, perform sensitivity and uncertainty analyses, and emphasize qualitative, robust predictions rather than narrow numeric thresholds.

2) Model simplification of astrocyte biology: astrocytes have complex regulation (regional heterogeneity, signaling, spatially varying metabolism) and interact with microglia and vasculature; the minimal model necessarily simplifies these layers. The goal is to establish whether shared buffering capacity can generically produce tipping behavior; positive results would motivate more detailed follow-up models.

3) Scaling from microcircuit to disease: Parkinson's disease progression involves systemic and longer-scale processes (immune activation, -synuclein spread) not modeled here. Our framework targets the local neighborhood-level mechanism and does not claim to account for all disease stages; integration with other mechanisms would be next steps.

4) Parameter identifiability and multiple hypotheses: multiple distinct mechanisms (mitochondrial bistability, proteostatic allocation, mtDNA clonal expansion) can produce similar phenomenology (long prodrome, rapid decline). We will design discriminative predictions (e.g., dependence on astrocyte:neuron ratio) that can be tested empirically to distinguish this model from neuron-intrinsic alternatives.

5) Computational complexity: spatial stochastic simulations with diffusion and many compartments may be computationally intensive. We'll use reduced mean-field analyses, adaptive simulation techniques (tau-leaping, hybrid deterministic-stochastic methods), and careful parameter pruning to keep experiments feasible on standard computational resources.

Name: mitofusion_fission_tipping
Title: Mitochondrial Network Tipping: How Fusion–Fission Dynamics Convert Pacemaking and Axonal Load into an Irreversible Energetic Collapse
Short Hypothesis: Differences in mitochondrial network dynamics (fusion vs fission balance and size-dependent mitophagy) create a dynamical tipping point: SNc neurons' high calcium pacemaking and long axons transiently bias fusion, producing large, interconnected mitochondrial networks that (a) spread ROS and mutant mtDNA, (b) blunt selective mitophagy, and (c) drive cooperative loss of OXPHOS function via a saddle-node bifurcation. VTA neurons avoid collapse because their mitochondrial dynamics keep the network in a fragmentation-dominated regime where damaged mitochondria are segregated and removed. This question is best addressed computationally because published quantitative rates for fusion/fission, mitophagy selectivity, transport, and calcium-driven modulation exist and can be integrated into stochastic, network-resolved models to reveal emergent topological transitions not visible in lumped energetic models.
Related Work: Empirical studies document (i) SNc vulnerability, high calcium pacemaking, and large axonal arbors; (ii) mitochondrial quality control via fission/fusion and size-dependent mitophagy (DRP1, OPA1, PINK1/Parkin pathways); and (iii) links between calcium signaling and fusion propensity. Prior theoretical work modeled whole-cell energetic bistability, arbor topology/percolation, proteostatic allocation, and mtDNA clonal expansion. However, none have modeled the intracellular mitochondrial network as an explicit dynamical graph with stochastic fusion/fission, size-dependent clearance, and activity-modulated rates to ask whether network topology itself undergoes a bifurcation that confers selective vulnerability. This proposal differs meaningfully by focusing on mitochondrial network topology and its regulation as the primary mechanism converting physiological pacemaking and structural load into a tipping point. It is not a trivial extension because fusion–fission network dynamics produce different thresholds, separatrix geometries, and intervention targets (modulating DRP1/OPA1 kinetics, mitophagy size thresholds) than lumped energy or proteostasis models.
Abstract: Selective degeneration of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons in Parkinson's disease remains unexplained by single-factor hypotheses. We propose that the emergent topology of the mitochondrial network—set by stochastic fusion and fission dynamics, size-dependent mitophagy, and activity-dependent modulation—creates a dynamical tipping point that renders SNc neurons uniquely vulnerable. High-frequency calcium pacemaking and extensive axonal demand transiently bias fusion (via calcium-sensitive OPA1/mitofusin regulation) and increase mitochondrial encounters in long arbors, promoting formation of large, interconnected mitochondrial reticula. These large structures dilute selective quality control: damaged mtDNA, oxidized proteins, and ROS can spread across the reticulum while mitophagy preferentially removes smaller, isolated fragments. We develop a literature-anchored stochastic network model in which discrete mitochondrial units (nodes) undergo fusion/fission, transport between soma and axon, size-dependent mitophagy, and activity-modulated fusion propensity. Mathematical and simulation analyses show that increasing pacemaking-driven fusion or effective encounter rates (scaled by axonal arborization) drives a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation: a healthy fragmented regime coexists with a pathological hyperfused regime characterized by high mutant load, low selective clearance, and collapsed ATP output. In parameter regimes calibrated from published fusion/fission kinetics, mitophagy selectivity, transport rates, and calcium-dependence, SNc-like ensembles fall inside the bistable band while VTA-like ensembles remain safely fragmented. Noise from transient insults or burst activity readily pushes SNc trajectories across the separatrix; hysteresis explains practical irreversibility. The theory yields quantitative, testable predictions about how much modulation of fission, fusion, or mitophagy would be needed to prevent collapse, and suggests mitochondrial dynamics as a high-leverage therapeutic axis.
Experiments: 1) Literature curation and priors: compile published quantitative rates and ranges for mitochondrial fusion and fission kinetics (GTPase activity and event rates; DRP1/OPA1/mitofusin kinetics), size-distribution statistics from imaging studies (mitochondrial length/area distributions in dopaminergic neurons), mitophagy selectivity functions (dependence of mitophagy probability on organelle size or membrane potential), anterograde/retrograde transport rates and pausing statistics, and calcium dependence of fusion propensity (from cell types including neurons). Collect SNc vs VTA comparative summaries for firing rates and axonal encounter probabilities where available. Assemble probabilistic priors for all parameters.

2) Minimal stochastic network model: implement an agent-based model where each mitochondrion is a discrete node with properties (size, membrane potential or functional score, mtDNA mutant fraction). Rules: (a) pairwise fusion occurs at rate k_f that can increase with local calcium activity and encounter rate (function of axonal arbor encounter parameter A); fused nodes combine size and mix contents; (b) fission splits a node into two with size-dependent partitioning at rate k_s (DRP1-mediated); (c) mitophagy removes nodes at rate k_m(size,functional) biased toward small or low-potential nodes (implement saturating selectivity); (d) mutation/oxidative damage accrues stochastically and propagates upon fusion; (e) transport moves nodes between compartments (soma, proximal axon, distal axon) with published transport kinetics. Implement in Python with an efficient event-driven Gillespie scheme for network events.

3) Reduced mean-field and bifurcation analysis: derive a coarse-grained two-variable approximation (mean node size S and mean functional mass M or fraction of damaged mass) capturing cooperative feedbacks (fusion increases mean size and mixing; larger size reduces mitophagy efficiency). Use continuation tools (pyDSTool/AUTO or numerical bifurcation scanning) to locate saddle-node folds as functions of effective encounter rate (scales with axonal arbor A) and activity-driven fusion modulation (scales with pacemaking calcium C). Compute hysteresis width and separatrix geometry.

4) Stochastic ensemble simulations: run many stochastic realizations for SNc-like and VTA-like parameter ensembles sampled from priors to estimate (a) probability of transition to hyperfused pathological regime under physiologically plausible noise and transient insults, (b) distribution of time-to-collapse (first-passage time to low functional mass), and (c) spatial patterns (where in arbor collapse nucleates). Metrics: probability of collapse by age proxy, median time-to-collapse, fraction of mitochondrial mass below membrane potential threshold, and mean size distribution.

5) Sensitivity and uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol or Morris) across prior distributions to rank parameters that most affect the bifurcation location and collapse probability (k_f, k_s, mitophagy selectivity steepness, transport rates, activity-coupling coefficients). Identify robust intervention targets.

6) In silico interventions and rescue tests: simulate perturbations reflecting published manipulations (increasing fission via DRP1 activation, inhibiting excessive fusion via OPA1/mitofusin knockdown, enhancing size-independent mitophagy via Parkin/PINK1 upregulation, or modestly reducing calcium entry) using literature-derived effect sizes when possible. Quantify how much parameter change is required to (a) prevent collapse across the SNc ensemble and (b) reverse hyperfusion if applied after collapse (measure hysteresis limits and rescue feasibility).

7) Plausibility checks against published imaging/biochemical data: compare model predictions qualitatively and quantitatively to reported mitochondrial morphology shifts, increased fused networks, and mitophagy impairment in SNc neurons from PD models or aged tissue. Use summarized imaging stats (length distributions, network connectivity metrics) to map real neurons onto the model's distance-to-tipping metric where data allow.

8) Release code and parameter database: publish the stochastic simulator, analysis scripts, and curated parameter priors to enable reproducibility and to let experimentalists map their mitochondrial imaging/biochemistry measurements onto model phase space.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty and cell-type data gaps: precise numerical rates for fusion/fission and mitophagy in SNc vs VTA in vivo are limited; conclusions may depend quantitatively on these values. Mitigation: use wide priors, Bayesian ensembles, sensitivity analysis, and emphasize robust qualitative phase-structure results rather than precise thresholds.

2) Model abstraction: the model simplifies complex molecular regulation (post-translational modifications, receptor signaling, inter-organelle contact sites) into rate laws. Although necessary to reveal network-level topology effects, some molecular subtleties may shift quantitative predictions; further mechanistic detail can be added later.

3) Computational cost: event-driven stochastic simulations with many mitochondrial agents, compartments, and long simulated lifespans can be computationally intensive. Mitigation: use hybrid approximations (tau-leaping, moment-closure), adaptive compartment aggregation, and focus on representative lifespan windows and parameter regimes to keep experiments feasible on standard lab hardware.

4) Causality vs correlation in published data: observed mitochondrial hyperfusion or mitophagy impairment in PD models may be downstream or parallel to other pathogenic processes. Our computational work seeks to show plausibility and sufficiency of a fusion–fission tipping mechanism, not to exclude other causal contributors. We will propose discriminative experimental predictions (e.g., rescue by increasing selective mitophagy without changing axonal load) to guide empirical testing.

5) Mapping network topology metrics from microscopy: connecting model-derived network connectivity metrics to typical microscopy readouts (e.g., 2D projected lengths, puncta counts) requires careful mapping and may introduce uncertainty. We'll provide mapping protocols and report sensitivity of conclusions to measurement-style transformations.

Name: multivariate_tail_tipping
Title: Multivariate Tail Tipping: How Joint Trait Covariance Creates a Vulnerable Subpopulation of Dopaminergic Neurons Near an Energetic Tipping Point
Short Hypothesis: Selective SNc vulnerability arises not from a single dominant factor but from the joint alignment (covariance) of many subthreshold risk traits (large arbor, high calcium load, low mitophagy/mitochondrial maintenance gene expression, proteostatic limits). Published single-cell and morphological datasets contain the empirical joint-distribution needed to locate a 'vulnerability axis' along which rare neurons (the distribution tail) sit close to an energetic saddle-node bifurcation. Small, population-level shifts in mean or variance with age (or increased trait correlations) produce abrupt increases in the fraction of neurons that stochastically tip into energetic collapse. This is best addressed computationally by learning the empirical multivariate trait distribution from published single-cell transcriptomics, reconstructions, and physiology summaries, mapping latent axes onto parameters of a minimal dynamical energetic model, and running population-level stochastic bifurcation simulations to quantify how covariance structure shapes population-scale risk.
Related Work: Prior work has identified many candidate causes of SNc vulnerability (large axonal arbors, calcium pacemaking, mitochondrial dysfunction, proteostatic stress) and shown that nonlinear mitochondrial dynamics can produce atomic bistability/tipping at the single-cell level. Other proposals focused on arbor topology/percolation, allocation of proteostatic flux, mtDNA dynamics, mitochondrial fusion/fission, or astrocytic buffering. However, most models treat cell types by mean parameter differences or single dominant mechanisms. Empirical single-cell/nucleus RNA-seq studies and recent morphological reconstructions reveal substantial cell-to-cell heterogeneity and covariance among risk-related traits. This proposal differs by (i) explicitly leveraging published multimodal population distributions to infer a vulnerability axis (a latent combination of traits), (ii) demonstrating that covariance — not just marginal means — determines the prevalence of cells near the tipping point, and (iii) linking population-level shifts (aging, inflammation) to sudden increases in collapse incidence. This is not a trivial extension: manipulating covariance can have outsized, non-additive effects (rare-event amplification) that qualitatively alter predictions and intervention priorities compared to single-parameter bifurcation models.
Abstract: Selective degeneration of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons is a hallmark of Parkinson's disease, but why anatomically and molecularly similar ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons largely survive remains unresolved. We propose that selective vulnerability reflects a multivariate tail phenomenon: the joint distribution of many modest risk traits (axonal arborization, autonomous calcium entry, mitochondrial maintenance gene expression, proteostasis capacity) contains a latent 'vulnerability axis' along which rare neurons reside precariously close to an energetic saddle-node bifurcation. Using only published data, we will (1) assemble multimodal summary statistics and single-cell/nucleus RNA-seq datasets for midbrain dopaminergic neurons and morphological reconstructions, (2) learn low-dimensional latent axes (CCA, PCA, probabilistic factor analysis) that combine molecular, physiological and anatomical features and quantify the empirical covariance structure, (3) map latent scores into parameters of a compact two-variable energetic model (mitochondrial functional mass and energetic reserve) via literature-grounded regression priors, and (4) simulate population ensembles under stochastic perturbations and aging-driven shifts in distribution moments to compute population-level first-passage times and abrupt increases in collapse incidence. We will show that (i) SNc populations have heavier tails along the vulnerability axis than VTA due to specific trait covariances, (ii) modest shifts in mean or increases in trait correlations with age can nonlinearly amplify the vulnerable tail fraction, and (iii) interventions that decorrelate risk traits or reduce variance can be more effective per unit effort than single-parameter interventions that change means. This framework explains selective vulnerability, variability in age of onset, and sudden clinical progression as emergent consequences of population-level geometry in phenotype space, and yields concrete, data-grounded predictions and intervention priorities that can be tested by mapping new measurements onto the learned vulnerability axis.
Experiments: 1) Data assembly and curation: gather published single-cell/single-nucleus RNA-seq datasets for midbrain dopaminergic neurons (mouse, rat, human where available), published morphological reconstructions and summary statistics (axon length, varicosity density), electrophysiological summaries (firing rate, calcium channel expression), and summary biochemical/mitochondrial metrics from literature (mitophagy gene expression, mitochondrial density). Standardize metadata and create harmonized feature tables (gene modules, morphological features, cell-type labels). Key sources will be named and documented in the project repo (e.g., midbrain scRNA-seq atlases, Pissadaki & Bolam datasets, Surmeier lab summaries).

2) Latent vulnerability axis discovery: using the assembled datasets, compute biologically informed features (e.g., expression module scores for mitochondrial maintenance, proteostasis, calcium channels; morphological scalar proxies). Apply canonical correlation analysis (CCA), probabilistic PCA, and a hierarchical Bayesian factor model to learn latent axes that maximally covary across modalities and that are interpretable (sparse loadings). Identify the principal latent axis that loads positively on risk features (large axon proxy, high calcium-channel expression) and negatively on protective features (high mitophagy/biogenesis gene scores). Quantify the empirical marginal and joint distributions along this axis separately for SNc and VTA neurons and estimate covariance matrices and tail-heaviness (kurtosis).

3) Mapping latent scores to dynamical model parameters: build a minimal two-state energetic model (mitochondrial capacity M, energetic reserve E) that exhibits a saddle-node bifurcation when load (function of axonal+calcium burden) exceeds mitochondrial recovery capacity. Using literature-derived mechanistic scalings (e.g., Pissadaki & Bolam-style energy demands per axon length; electrophysiology-derived calcium load), learn regression mappings from latent axis scores to model parameters (axonal load A, calcium burden C, mitophagy/biogenesis effective rate μ) with uncertainty (Bayesian linear model). This produces a probabilistic mapping from each empirical neuron (or cell cluster) to a point in model parameter space.

4) Population stochastic bifurcation simulations: sample synthetic neuronal populations from the empirical joint-distribution (preserving covariance) and simulate stochastic dynamics of each sample using the two-variable model with physiologically plausible noise. For each population, compute the fraction of neurons that collapse over simulated lifespan, distribution of first-passage times, and how these change under small shifts in mean and covariance (aging, inflammation proxies). Evaluate how preserving vs removing empirical correlations (i.e., shuffling features to break covariance) alters collapse incidence.

5) Sensitivity and intervention ranking: perform global sensitivity analysis across the empirical parameter-to-model mapping to rank which trait combinations (mean changes vs variance/covariance changes) most strongly affect population collapse probability. Evaluate intervention strategies: (a) reduce mean of a key trait (e.g., lower firing rate), (b) reduce variance across population (e.g., homoeostatic regulation), (c) decorrelate protective and risky traits (e.g., raise mitophagy specifically in high-arbor cells). For each, compute required effect sizes to reduce collapse fraction by target amounts and compare cost-effectiveness under plausible biological constraints.

6) Validation and plausibility checks: compare model-predicted vulnerable-fraction trajectories and age-dependence to published neuropathology statistics (e.g., fraction SNc loss in aging/PD cohorts) and to any available single-cell studies of PD vs control changes in expression distributions. Test whether latent vulnerability scores on published PD samples are enriched among cells showing stress signatures. Use ROC/precision-recall to assess how well the vulnerability axis discriminates reported vulnerability indicators from the literature.

7) Robustness and alternative models: test alternate latent extraction methods, nonlinear embeddings (variational autoencoders), and different mappings from latent scores to dynamical parameters (nonlinear link functions). Report which qualitative conclusions (tail-driven sudden increases in collapse) are robust across modeling choices.

8) Open code, data packages, and visualization: release all curated feature matrices, code to learn vulnerability axes, mapping scripts, stochastic simulators, and interactive visualizations so experimentalists can project new measurements onto the vulnerability axis and compute 'distance-to-tipping' metrics.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Cross-modality mapping uncertainty: aligning gene-expression modules, morphological proxies, and physiology into a single feature space requires care; many datasets are from different species, ages, or measurement platforms. Mitigation: use batch-correction and hierarchical models, perform species-specific analyses and then cross-validate qualitative patterns, and emphasize robust qualitative predictions.

2) Mapping latent scores to biophysical model parameters is indirect: regression from expression/morphology to energetic parameters carries uncertainty and potential confounding. Mitigation: use Bayesian regression with wide priors, propagate uncertainty into population simulations, and focus on relative changes (effect of covariance) rather than precise numeric tipping thresholds.

3) Data sparsity for key morphological features: single-cell RNA-seq datasets lack matched axonal reconstructions for the same cells; morphological-statistics will come from separate studies and must be combined at the population-level not single-cell level. Mitigation: treat morphological features as population priors and propagate variance; where possible, use multimodal published datasets (Patch-seq or combined imaging+transcriptomics) to strengthen mappings.

4) Model misspecification risk: the two-variable energetic model is intentionally minimal; real neurons have many more interacting processes (proteostasis, mtDNA, glial support). The aim is to show how population geometry alters tipping probabilities given any single-cell bistability mechanism; specific molecular details can be layered in future work.

5) Interpretation and causal claims: correlation/covariance observed in datasets may be developmental or compensatory rather than causal risks. We will be cautious in causal language, present falsifiable predictions (e.g., that reducing covariance reduces collapse incidence), and propose experimental tests (targeted upregulation of mitophagy in high-arbor neurons) for validation.

Name: homeostatic_maladaptation_tipping
Title: Homeostatic Maladaptation: Control-Loop Driven Tipping Points in Vulnerable Dopaminergic Neurons
Short Hypothesis: Cell-autonomous homeostatic control that maintains firing rate and synaptic output (via intrinsic excitability and synaptic scaling) becomes maladaptive under chronic structural/metabolic stress: the controller increases gain to preserve function, raising calcium influx and energetic demand and thereby accelerating mitochondrial decline until the system crosses a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation. This control-loop–driven drift produces long prodromes followed by rapid, effectively irreversible collapse, explaining selective SNc vulnerability vs VTA. Testing this requires integrating published homeostatic plasticity kinetics, electrophysiological setpoints, energetic cost-per-spike, and mitochondrial aging data into a dynamical control model—something only feasible with literature-derived data and computational analysis, not simpler static comparisons.
Related Work: Empirical work documents SNc vs VTA differences (axonal arbors, pacemaking calcium, mitochondrial fragility) and many theoretical models propose energetic bistability, proteostatic allocation, or arbor-topology percolation as tipping mechanisms. Separately, the neuroscience literature establishes robust homeostatic plasticity mechanisms (synaptic scaling, intrinsic excitability regulation) that maintain firing-rate setpoints on slow timescales (Turrigiano and colleagues). Prior PD-relevant models have not coupled explicit homeostatic controllers to cellular energetics and mitochondrial decline. This proposal differs by treating homeostatic regulation as an active feedback controller that (i) adapts on intermediate timescales, (ii) modifies energetic demand as a function of perceived functional error, and (iii) can therefore drive a neuron into a bifurcation that would not occur in the absence of adaptation. Unlike prior ideas, maladaptive homeostasis provides a mechanistic explanation for gradual compensation followed by abrupt failure and proposes distinct intervention levers (controller gain, setpoint, timescale) that are different from reducing static load or boosting clearance alone.
Abstract: Dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) are preferentially lost in Parkinson's disease while neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons survive. Existing mechanistic accounts emphasize axonal load, calcium stress, and mitochondrial dysfunction, often cast as static risk factors or as mechanisms producing single-cell bistability. Here we propose a complementary, control-theoretic explanation: neuronal homeostatic plasticity—synaptic scaling and intrinsic excitability regulation that maintain firing-rate setpoints—acts as a feedback controller that becomes maladaptive under chronic structural and energetic stress. As mitochondrial capacity declines with age, the controller compensates by increasing gain (e.g., boosting excitability or upscaling synapses) to maintain output. This compensation increases calcium entry and spiking-related energy use, accelerating mitochondrial damage and creating a positive feedback loop that drives the system through a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation into a collapsed low-energy state. We construct a minimal three-variable dynamical model (mitochondrial capacity M, energetic reserve E, homeostatic gain G) parameterized from published electrophysiology, homeostatic plasticity kinetics, Pissadaki & Bolam-style energetic cost estimates, and mitochondrial aging literature. Mathematical bifurcation analysis and stochastic simulations show that (i) controller adaptation creates a delayed tipping behavior (long compensation/prodrome, then rapid collapse), (ii) SNc-like parameter ensembles lie closer to the bifurcation than VTA-like ensembles because of larger effective load and different controller sensitivities, and (iii) modulating controller parameters (reducing gain, lowering setpoint, slowing adaptation) can be more effective than equivalently sized reductions in static load. This framework reframes PD vulnerability as an emergent failure mode of homeostatic regulation and yields empirically testable, literature-grounded predictions about which measurable changes (e.g., altered excitability setpoints, expression of homeostatic molecules) indicate proximity to tipping.
Experiments: 1) Literature assembly and priors: compile quantitative priors from published work for (a) neuronal firing-rate setpoints and homeostatic plasticity kinetics (time constants for intrinsic excitability and synaptic scaling from cultured neurons and in vivo studies, e.g., Turrigiano lab and follow-ups), (b) cost-per-spike and calcium-entry per spike estimates (from Pissadaki & Bolam, Surmeier lab, and electrophysiology reports), (c) axonal arbor/varicosity-derived energetic load differences for SNc vs VTA, and (d) age-dependent mitochondrial capacity decline rates (mtDNA/mitophagy/functional OXPHOS declines). Produce probabilistic priors for all key parameters.

2) Minimal control-theoretic model construction: implement a compact ODE model with three core variables: M(t) mitochondrial functional capacity, E(t) energetic reserve/ATP available, and G(t) homeostatic gain controlling effective firing-related demand. Example form: dE/dt = production(M,E) - Demand(G,A,C,E); dM/dt = biogenesis(M,E) - damage(Demand,ROS)*M; dG/dt = (1/τ)[K*(r_target - r_eff(E, G, A)) - lambda*G] where r_eff is effective firing/output (function of intrinsic excitability G and homeostatic scaling), K is controller gain, τ its timescale, lambda baseline decay. Demand increases with G and anatomical load A and calcium burden C. Build variants where homeostasis acts via synaptic scaling vs intrinsic excitability and where adaptation targets different setpoints.

3) Deterministic bifurcation and control-parameter analysis: use continuation tools (AUTO, pyDSTool, MatCont) to perform bifurcation analysis in key axes: controller gain K, adaptation timescale τ, firing setpoint r_target, and anatomical load A. Identify saddle-node folds, hysteresis width, and parameter regimes where adaptation shifts system into bistability. Analyze how changing controller parameters moves the bifurcation point and alters basin geometry.

4) Stochastic ensemble simulations and first-passage times: add physiologically plausible noise (transient mitochondrial insults, fluctuations in firing or dopamine oxidation) and run Monte Carlo simulations for SNc- and VTA-like parameter ensembles sampled from priors to compute probability and timing of collapse. Metrics: mean first-passage to collapse, collapse probability by simulated age, sensitivity to noise amplitude, and distribution of times between onset of maladaptive compensation and collapse.

5) Cross-mapping SNc vs VTA: map literature-derived differences (A, C, baseline G or homeostatic expression markers) into the model to compare distance-to-tipping for SNc and VTA ensembles. Quantify how much altering controller parameters alone (e.g., lowering K or r_target) changes vulnerability relative to reducing anatomical load.

6) Sensitivity and intervention effect-size quantification: global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) to rank which parameters (K, τ, r_target, mitophagy rate, damage coupling strength) most influence tipping. Simulate interventions: (i) reduce K (pharmacologically blunt homeostatic upregulation), (ii) lower r_target (mimic chronic reduced demand), (iii) slow adaptation τ (make compensation slower), and (iv) boost mitochondrial biogenesis. Compute effect sizes required to delay tipping by target durations or reduce collapse probability by 50% under uncertainty.
