7) Predictive biomarker proposals: translate model variables into measurable proxies (e.g., expression levels of homeostatic markers like Arc/HCN channel regulation, intrinsic excitability assays, changes in firing-rate variability) and propose literature-mapped thresholds whose observation in existing datasets would indicate proximity to tipping. Where possible, test feasibility by re-analyzing published electrophysiology or transcriptomic summary statistics to see if SNc neurons show signatures consistent with higher homeostatic gain/load.

8) Code and reproducibility: release all model code, curated parameter priors, simulation notebooks, and visualization scripts to allow other groups to map their measurements onto the model's distance-to-tipping metric.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty and timescale mismatch: reliable quantitative measures for in vivo homeostatic plasticity timescales and setpoints in mature midbrain dopaminergic neurons are limited. This may limit precise timing predictions. Mitigation: use wide priors, sensitivity analysis, and emphasize qualitative behaviors (existence of controller-driven bifurcation) rather than exact ages.

2) Model abstraction of homeostatic mechanisms: synaptic scaling and intrinsic excitability are implemented here as simplified control laws; molecular signaling complexity (transcriptional programs, neuromodulators) is abstracted. The aim is to capture generic control feedbacks and their dynamical consequences; future work could add molecular layers if warranted.

3) Multiple interacting mechanisms: homeostatic maladaptation may interact with proteostasis, mtDNA dynamics, fusion/fission, or astrocytic buffering—mechanisms explored in other proposals. This model isolates control-loop effects; combined mechanisms could amplify or mitigate tipping and should be explored later.

4) Mapping to available data: mapping modeled controller variables to concrete, published biomarkers (e.g., gene expression scores) may be noisy or indirect. We will propose several candidate proxies and test robustness across them, but empirical validation may require new targeted measurements.

5) Intervention interpretability: proposals to 'reduce homeostatic gain' or 'lower setpoint' are mechanistically abstract and may be challenging to translate directly into safe biological interventions. The value here is in identifying control-theoretic levers (slower adaptation, lower firing setpoint) and quantifying their required effect sizes; experimental translation will require careful biological design and safety considerations.

Name: vascular_microdomain_tipping
Title: Vascular Microdomain Tipping: How Local Capillary Geometry and Activity-Dependent Oxygen Demand Produce an Irreversible Energetic Collapse in Vulnerable Dopaminergic Neurons
Short Hypothesis: Microvascular microarchitecture (capillary density, spacing, and perfusion reserve) creates spatially heterogeneous oxygen/glucose supply such that SNc dopaminergic arbors experience intermittent local hypoxic microdomains during normal activity. Coupled nonlinear mitochondrial respiration produces a load- and supply-dependent saddle-node bifurcation: when anatomical and age-related vascular constraints reduce local supply below a topology-dependent threshold, neurons enter a bistable regime where physiological noise triggers stochastic, hysteretic energetic collapse. This hypothesis can be tested purely computationally by combining published microvascular and metabolic summary statistics with diffusion-reaction and compartmental energetic models—offering a distinct vascular-centric mechanism complementary to neuron-intrinsic and glial models and producing falsifiable, quantitative predictions about vascular metrics that control vulnerability.
Related Work: Prior work emphasized neuron-intrinsic determinants (axon arbor size, calcium pacemaking, mitochondrial dynamics, proteostasis) and glial buffering as drivers of selective vulnerability. Pissadaki & Bolam and follow-ups quantified axonal energetic cost; other studies implicate mitochondrial dysfunction and calcium stress. Separately, literature in neurovascular physiology provides capillary density, oxygen diffusion coefficients, and local cerebral metabolic rate estimates. However, models linking microvascular geometry and perfusion reserve to single-neuron energetic tipping are scarce. This proposal differs by centering microvascular supply geometry as the primary bifurcation control parameter, integrating spatial oxygen/glucose diffusion-reaction PDEs with nonlinear mitochondrial respiration and axonal demand distributions. Unlike astrocytic-buffering or arbor-percolation models, the vascular microdomain mechanism predicts specific anatomical vascular metrics (local capillary spacing, perfusion heterogeneity, reserve fraction) that determine the existence and location of a bistable band, and yields different intervention targets (augment perfusion reserve, microvascular remodeling) whose predicted effect sizes are quantifiable from published data.
Abstract: Selective loss of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons in Parkinson's disease contrasts with relative sparing of nearby ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons despite many shared cell-intrinsic features. We propose a vascular microdomain tipping hypothesis: spatial heterogeneity in capillary geometry and perfusion reserve creates local oxygen/glucose supply microdomains that, when combined with the exceptionally large axonal arbors and high calcium-driven demand of SNc neurons, push mitochondria into a nonlinear, cooperative regime exhibiting a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation. Using published measures of capillary density, intercapillary distance, cerebral blood flow variability, oxygen diffusion constants, and neuronal energetic costs, we will build a spatial diffusion-reaction model of tissue oxygen/glucose coupled to a minimal nonlinear mitochondrial respiration/energetic-reserve model distributed across realistic axonal arbor geometries. Deterministic bifurcation analysis and stochastic simulations will determine conditions for bistability, first-passage times to collapse under physiological noise and age-related vascular decline, and hysteresis (practical irreversibility) due to anatomical constraints on increasing local perfusion or pruning axons. Mapping literature-derived SNc and VTA vascular and anatomical parameter ensembles into phase space predicts that SNc neurons occupy a bistable band while VTA neurons remain monostable. The model yields falsifiable quantitative predictions: critical capillary spacing and perfusion-reserve thresholds, required percent increases in local blood flow to avert tipping, and differential vulnerability across species and brain regions. All code, parameter ensembles, and analysis will be released to enable experimental mapping and targeted vascular interventions.
Experiments: 1) Literature synthesis and parameter priors: curate published quantitative data for (a) capillary density/intercapillary distance and heterogeneity in SNc and VTA (rodent, primate, human where available), (b) baseline and reserve cerebral blood flow (CBF) and oxygen extraction fraction metrics, (c) oxygen and glucose diffusion coefficients in brain tissue, (d) local neuronal energetic demand per unit axonal varicosity/firing (from Pissadaki & Bolam-type estimates), and (e) age-related decline in microvascular perfusion/CBF. Compile probabilistic priors for all parameters to capture cross-study uncertainty.

2) Spatial diffusion-reaction model: implement a 2D/3D diffusion-reaction PDE model for oxygen (and optionally glucose) in tissue surrounding a neuron's axonal arbor. Source terms: capillaries modeled as discrete line/point sources with specified perfusion flux and oxygen partial pressure; sink terms: neuronal oxygen consumption distributed along the arbor proportional to local varicosity density and firing-driven demand. Use published Michaelis-Menten respiration kinetics to couple substrate concentration to ATP production in local mitochondria; include nonlinear cooperative drop-off in ATP production at low O2 (to enable saddle-node geometry). Solve stationary and time-dependent PDEs with finite-element (FEniCS or SciPy/Sparse) or finite-difference schemes.

3) Reduced compartmental dynamical model and bifurcation analysis: derive a low-dimensional reduction in which localized tissue oxygen supply to key compartments (soma, proximal axon, distal arbor clusters) is represented by coupled ODEs linking supply, demand, and mitochondrial capacity M and energetic reserve E. Calibrate nonlinear respiration functions (e.g., Hill-type O2 dependence) so that production vs O2 has cooperativity producing saddle-node folds. Use continuation tools (AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont) to locate saddle-node bifurcations as functions of capillary spacing, perfusion reserve, and axonal-demand parameters.

4) Mapping SNc vs VTA ensembles: sample parameter ensembles for SNc and VTA from the literature-derived priors (capillary density, varicosity density, firing rates) and map them into the reduced model/PDE simulations to determine for each sample whether it lies in monostable or bistable regime. Compute distribution of distance-to-tipping metrics (e.g., delta perfusion required to cross fold) for both populations.

5) Stochastic simulations and first-passage analysis: add physiologically plausible noise sources (transient drops in local perfusion, spontaneous mitochondrial insults, firing-rate variability) and run ensemble stochastic simulations to estimate first-passage times to energetic collapse for SNc- vs VTA-like parameter sets. Compute collapse probability as a function of age-like gradual decline in perfusion reserve.

6) Sensitivity and uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) across priors to rank which vascular or neuronal parameters most influence tipping (capillary spacing variance, reserve fraction, diffusion constant, local varicosity clustering). Identify robust intervention levers under uncertainty.

7) In silico intervention evaluation: simulate candidate interventions drawn from literature effect sizes (e.g., increasing local perfusion by X% via angiogenic or vasodilatory strategies, reducing local demand via modest firing reduction, or improving oxygen extraction) to compute required effect sizes to avert tipping or to rescue after collapse. Compare feasibility of vascular vs neuronal-targeted interventions quantitatively.

8) Validation & literature consistency checks: compare model predictions to published anatomical/functional patterns (e.g., regional susceptibility maps, reported microinfarct or hypoperfusion associations with PD) and verify that predicted critical vascular metrics align with any available human/animal data; propose specific empirically testable vascular markers (capillary spacing, local CBF reserve) to distinguish this mechanism from alternatives.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data sparsity and heterogeneity: high-resolution capillary density and perfusion-reserve measurements specifically for SNc vs VTA across species (especially human) are limited. Mitigation: use broad priors, cross-species scaling where justified, and sensitivity/uncertainty quantification to identify qualitative, robust predictions.

2) Model simplifications: coupling complex neurovascular regulation (neurovascular coupling, dynamic autoregulation, astrocyte-mediated flow control) is simplified here. The model aims to test plausibility of a vascular microdomain tipping mechanism; positive results would motivate layering in more regulatory detail in future work.

3) Parameter identifiability: many parameter combinations (supply, demand, cooperativity) can produce similar bifurcation structure. Mitigation: focus on geometric/topological features (existence of bistable band, dependence on capillary spacing) and on relative predictions (SNc vs VTA) rather than exact numeric thresholds.

4) Interaction with other mechanisms: vascular supply likely interacts with astrocytic buffering, proteostasis, and mitochondrial genetics; isolating vascular effects may under- or over-estimate real vulnerability. The proposal treats vascular microdomain limitation as a distinct, testable contributor complementary to prior neuron-intrinsic hypotheses.

5) Translational uncertainty for interventions: suggested vascular-targeting interventions (angiogenesis, perfusion augmentation) have systemic effects and may be difficult to translate safely; the model quantifies required effect sizes to inform experimental prioritization but does not address clinical safety.

Name: trafficking_resonance_tipping
Title: Trafficking–Resonance Tipping: How Timescale Mismatch Between Mitochondrial Transport and Stochastic Synaptic Demand Creates Temporal Bifurcations Driving Selective Neuronal Collapse
Short Hypothesis: A timescale mismatch and stochastic resonance between slow, bursty mitochondrial transport/redistribution and fast, correlated synaptic ATP demand (vesicle recycling + calcium transients + dopamine oxidation) creates transient supply deficits that accumulate damage and produce a load- and timing-induced saddle-node-like tipping point. SNc neurons, with dense varicosities and particular firing burst statistics, lie in parameter regimes where transport-demand resonance yields recurrent deep ATP troughs that stochastically push the cell across a separatrix into irreversible energetic collapse—while VTA neurons avoid these resonant regimes. This hypothesis is best tested computationally by integrating published transport kinetics, vesicle-release/cost statistics, and dopamine oxidation/ROS rates into compartmental stochastic transport–supply–demand models and analyzing temporal bifurcations (resonance tongues, Floquet-like instabilities) and stochastic first-passage behavior.
Related Work: Existing literature implicates large axonal arbors, high calcium pacemaking, mitochondrial dysfunction, impaired mitophagy, and arbor-topology percolation as drivers of SNc vulnerability. Prior models either (i) treat neurons as temporally lumped energy units (static load vs recovery bifurcations), (ii) examine spatial percolation along arbors with transport limits, or (iii) study mitochondrial network dynamics, proteostatic allocation, or mtDNA stochasticity. None explicitly analyze how the temporal statistics of mitochondrial transport (run/pausing times, intermittent anterograde flux) interact with stochastic synaptic demand patterns (Poisson or bursty release, correlated bursts) to produce resonant depletion events and temporal bifurcations. This proposal differs by focusing on time-scale mismatch and resonance: slow, intermittent replenishment can synchronize poorly with fast, correlated demand to create recurrent deep ATP troughs whose cumulative damage induces tipping. The mechanism is not a trivial extension of spatial percolation or lumped bistability because temporal coherence and transport scheduling produce distinct resonance phenomena (Arnold-tongue–like domains, Floquet instabilities) and different intervention strategies (altering transport time scales or firing temporal statistics) that are both measurable and manipulable.
Abstract: Why do substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons degenerate in Parkinson's disease while neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons are spared? Structural load and mitochondrial dysfunction explain much, but they do not account for how physiologically plausible temporal patterns of supply and demand produce long prodromes followed by rapid collapse. We propose a novel, literature-grounded computational mechanism: a timescale mismatch and stochastic resonance between slow, intermittent mitochondrial transport/redistribution and fast, bursty synaptic ATP demand creates temporal bifurcations that precipitate irreversible energetic collapse. Leveraging published mitochondrial transport kinetics (velocities, run lengths, pausing), varicosity densities, vesicle-release statistics and ATP cost-per-release, calcium transient energetics, and dopamine oxidation/ROS generation rates, we will construct a compartmental, stochastic model along realistic axonal arbors in which discrete mitochondria move, pause, and exchange while local ATP pools are consumed by stochastic release events and calcium handling. Deterministic reductions and Floquet-style analysis identify resonant parameter bands (timing 'tongues') where periodic or correlated inputs synchronize demand to create deep ATP troughs; stochastic simulations show these troughs increase likelihood of crossing a damage-dependent separatrix into a collapsed attractor. Using literature-derived SNc vs VTA parameter ensembles, we predict that SNc neurons lie inside resonance domains where physiologic noise suffices to trigger collapse and hysteresis makes rescue impractical. The theory yields falsifiable, quantitative predictions about how modifying transport kinetics, altering firing burst statistics, or redistributing varicosities changes collapse risk. All code, parameter priors, and analysis will be shared to enable mapping of new experimental data onto a 'temporal-distance-to-tipping' metric.
Experiments: 1) Parameter curation and priors: compile quantitative published data to form probabilistic priors: mitochondrial transport parameters (anterograde/retrograde velocities, run lengths, pausing probabilities, docking/un-docking rates) from neuronal imaging studies; axonal varicosity density and spatial layouts (SNc vs VTA reconstructions); vesicle release statistics per varicosity (baseline Poisson rates, burst probabilities, paired-pulse/facilitation data) and ATP cost per vesicle recycling; calcium transient amplitude/duration per spike and associated ATP cost; dopamine oxidation rates and ROS production per release event; and mitophagy/repair damage accumulation rates. Assemble these into parameter ensembles with uncertainties.

2) Compartmental stochastic transport–supply–demand model: implement a discrete, event-driven model along an axonal arbor segmented into compartments corresponding to varicosities/segments. Agents: mitochondria (each with local ATP-production capacity and health score) move via continuous-time Markov chain rules (run, pause, reverse) parameterized from literature. Local ATP pool dynamics: dA_i/dt = production_from_local_mitochondria - consumption_from_release_and_Ca - diffusion_to_neighboring_pools. Vesicle-release events at compartment i follow empirically parameterized point processes (Poisson or inhomogeneous bursty processes, with controllable correlation between nearby varicosities). Include dopamine-oxidation-produced ROS bursts tied to release events that increment damage of nearby mitochondria. Damage accumulates stochastically and reduces mitochondrial production; define collapse as soma/aggregate ATP reserve falling below threshold. Implement efficient Gillespie/event-driven simulation in Python (NumPy) with optional Cython acceleration for large arbors.

3) Deterministic and periodic-analysis reduction: derive reduced mean-field ODEs and periodically forced linearization around time-periodic demand to perform Floquet/stability analysis. Identify resonant regimes (timing 'tongues') where periodic or quasi-periodic demand synchronizes with transport timescales to amplify ATP minima. Use numerical continuation (AUTO/pyDSTool) to map stability boundaries in the (transport timescale, burst-frequency) plane and characterize saddle-node–like fold creation as a function of transport/demand parameters.

4) Stochastic ensemble simulations for SNc vs VTA: sample parameter ensembles reflecting literature-derived SNc and VTA ranges (varicosity density, firing/burst statistics, mitochondrial traffic) and run many stochastic realizations per ensemble to compute: probability of collapse in a given simulated timeframe, distribution of first-passage times to collapse, statistics of local ATP minima depth and duration, and correlation of collapse events with resonant alignment metrics (e.g., coherence between burst events and recent replenishment arrivals). Evaluate how physiologically plausible noise levels affect risk.

5) Temporal coherence and spectral metrics: compute power spectra and coherence measures between demand (aggregate release rate) and supply (mitochondrial arrivals/local production) to quantify resonance. Identify whether high coherence or specific phase lags precede collapse events; test predictive power of these temporal biomarkers for first-passage occurrence.

6) Sensitivity and identifiability analysis: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) over priors to rank which parameters (mean run length, pausing fraction, burst probability, varicosity density, damage accumulation rate) most shift the resonant tongues and collapse probability. Produce robust intervention rankings under uncertainty.

7) In silico intervention and rescue tests: simulate candidate interventions drawn from literature effect sizes—(a) speeding mitochondrial transport (increasing mean velocity or reducing pausing), (b) increasing docking probability near soma, (c) reducing synchrony of release (desynchronizing bursting), (d) modest reductions in firing rate or burst propensity, and (e) enhancing local mitochondrial buffering capacity (e.g., increased local glycolytic ATP supply). Quantify required effect sizes to: (i) move SNc ensembles out of resonant domains, (ii) reduce collapse probability by target fractions, and (iii) rescue post-collapse where possible.

8) Mapping to published observations & falsifiable predictions: compare model-predicted distinguishing temporal biomarkers (e.g., phase-locking index thresholds, spectral peaks) to any existing electrophysiology/imaging literature that reports burst statistics in vulnerable neurons. Produce concrete, falsifiable predictions: e.g., blocking synchronous bursting or modestly increasing transport velocity by X% should reduce first-passage probability by Y%—values computed with uncertainty bands.

9) Code, data, reproducibility: release all curated parameter priors, simulator code, notebooks, and visualization dashboards so experimentalists can project new transport or firing measurements onto the model's 'temporal-distance-to-tipping' metric.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty and heterogeneity: precise in vivo measures linking vesicle-release statistics at individual varicosities, local ATP cost, and mitochondrial transport kinetics in adult human SNc vs VTA are limited. Mitigation: use wide priors, hierarchical/meta-analytic assembly of published values, and perform sensitivity analyses; focus on qualitative identification of resonant domains rather than precise numeric thresholds.

2) Model abstraction and scale reduction: the compartmental model simplifies many molecular details (e.g., local glycolysis, ER–mitochondria Ca2+ coupling, detailed ROS chemistry). The goal is to reveal timing/resonance effects that are generic; if positive, results would motivate targeted experimental follow-up with finer biochemical detail.

3) Computational cost for large arbors: event-driven stochastic simulation across many compartments and long simulated lifespans can be computationally intensive. Mitigation: employ accelerated sampling (tau-leaping where valid), representative-subgraph sampling, and efficient Cython/Numba-backed code to keep experiments feasible on standard lab hardware.

4) Distinguishing this mechanism empirically: resonance-driven tipping may co-occur with other mechanisms (percolation, proteostatic allocation, mtDNA effects), making causal attribution from existing data challenging. We will propose discriminative temporal biomarkers (coherence/phase metrics) that can be measured experimentally to distinguish temporal resonance from purely spatially driven collapse.

5) Translational intervention mapping: interventions such as speeding mitochondrial transport or decorrelating release dynamics may be hard to achieve safely in vivo. The project focuses on quantifying required effect sizes so experimentalists can judge feasibility; clinical translation would need careful further work.

Name: glymphatic_sleep_tipping
Title: Sleep–Glymphatic Collapse: How Age-Related Sleep Fragmentation Impairs Interstitial Clearance and Triggers a Tipping Point for Nigral Dopaminergic Failure
Short Hypothesis: Age-related sleep fragmentation reduces glymphatic (CSF–ISF) clearance of extracellular proteopathic species (α‑synuclein oligomers, dopamine oxidation products) and metabolic waste. In brain regions with dense dopaminergic terminal fields (SNc) this slowed clearance allows cooperative extracellular accumulation that accelerates local mitochondrial damage and proteostatic overload, driving a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation and bistability in neuronal energetic state. VTA regions, with lower extracellular source density and different interstitial geometry, remain safely monostable. This systemic sleep-to-clearance pathway uniquely links prodromal sleep disturbances in PD to later, rapid, and effectively irreversible cellular collapse and is testable by integrating published glymphatic, aggregation and neuronal energetic data into spatial reaction–diffusion plus dynamical-system models.
Related Work: Empirical studies established (i) sleep-dependent enhancement of interstitial solute clearance (glymphatic system) and its reduction with aging and sleep fragmentation (e.g., decreased CSF–ISF flux during wake/aged states), (ii) prodromal sleep disorders (RBD, sleep fragmentation) strongly predict later PD, and (iii) extracellular α‑synuclein seeds and dopamine oxidation products contribute to local toxicity and mitochondrial dysfunction. Prior computational proposals focused on neuron-intrinsic energetic tipping (axon load, mtDNA, proteostatic allocation), astrocytic buffering of ROS/lactate, or spatial percolation along arbors. The present proposal differs by (a) elevating systemic, sleep-modulated interstitial clearance as the primary control parameter that couples organismal behavior (sleep quality) to local extracellular accumulation kinetics, (b) modeling CSF–ISF flow and diffusion-reaction in tissue microdomains around axonal terminal fields and coupling that to local aggregate kinetics and an energetic bistability model, and (c) producing falsifiable predictions linking quantified sleep/glymphatic metrics to cellular risk—an axis not addressed by purely cell-autonomous or astrocyte-only models.
Abstract: Parkinson’s disease (PD) features a long prodromal phase (often including sleep disturbances) followed by relatively rapid loss of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons. Why systemic prodromal phenomena (sleep loss) presage a spatially selective, topologically irreversible neuronal collapse is unclear. We hypothesize that sleep-regulated glymphatic clearance of extracellular proteopathic/molecular wastes (α‑synuclein oligomers, dopamine oxidation products, ROS byproducts) crucially modulates local extracellular load in regions with dense dopaminergic terminals. Aging and sleep fragmentation reduce glymphatic flux, slowing interstitial solute removal; in SNc microdomains this permits cooperative accumulation that feeds back to accelerate mitochondrial damage and proteostatic burden. Coupling literature-derived glymphatic flow rates, diffusion coefficients, aggregation/clearance kinetics, and neuronal energetic-bistability models, we will build spatial reaction–diffusion PDE models of extracellular solute dynamics around realistic terminal-field geometries and link them to a minimal two-variable neuronal energetic model (mitochondrial functional mass M, energetic reserve E) that admits a saddle-node bifurcation under increased extracellular-mediated damage. Deterministic continuation locates sleep-dependent bifurcation folds; stochastic simulations quantify first-passage collapse probabilities under physiologically plausible sleep fragmentation profiles and age-dependent decline of clearance. We predict that modest reductions in nocturnal glymphatic flux (within reported sleep-disorder magnitudes) can move SNc ensembles into a bistable band, such that normal physiological noise suffices to trigger collapse; hysteresis makes rescue by later restoring sleep insufficient unless glymphatic flux is boosted beyond anatomically implausible levels. This framework links behavioral, systemic, and local anatomical data into a concrete, testable mechanism explaining selective vulnerability, prodromal sleep associations, and effective irreversibility in PD.
Experiments: 1) Literature curation and priors: assemble quantitative published values and uncertainties for nocturnal vs diurnal glymphatic/CSF–ISF flux amplitudes, age-dependent decline in clearance, interstitial diffusion coefficients for α‑synuclein and DA-quinones, extracellular aggregation/oligomerization kinetics (nucleation/elongation rates), extracellular proteolytic/clearance rates, dopamine release per varicosity, varicosity densities for SNc and VTA, and mitochondrial damage coupling coefficients to extracellular aggregate/ROS concentration. Produce probabilistic priors for each parameter.

2) Spatial reaction–diffusion PDE model of interstitial domain: implement a 2D/3D diffusion-reaction model where capillary/CSF boundary conditions and sleep-state modulate advective glymphatic flux (parameter Phi_sleep). Place distributed source terms along anatomically informed axonal terminal-field geometries (use published reconstructions or synthetic fields parameterized by varicosity density). Reaction terms: aggregation nucleation/elongation for α‑synuclein (cooperative kinetics), formation of dopamine oxidation products per release event, and enzymatic/extracellular proteolysis tied to astrocytic/extracellular clearance capacity. Solve with finite-difference or finite-element methods (FEniCS or SciPy) under different sleep/age fluxes.

3) Coupling to neuronal energetic bistability: map local interstitial aggregate/ROS concentration C(x,t) to an increased mitochondrial damage rate in a minimal two-variable neuronal model (dM/dt = biogenesis(M,E) - damage(C)*M ; dE/dt = production(M) - Demand(A,Ca)*E). Choose simple nonlinear recovery (cooperative biogenesis) so the system can undergo a saddle-node bifurcation as damage increases. Parameterize axial/whole-cell mapping from local extracellular field to somatic damage via spatial averaging weighted by terminal density.

4) Deterministic bifurcation analysis: perform continuation on key parameters: nocturnal glymphatic flux amplitude Phi_sleep, age-dependent decline scalar, and local varicosity density A to find saddle-node folds and locate bistable bands. Compute hysteresis width and separatrix geometry and map where literature-derived SNc and VTA ensembles fall relative to folds.

5) Stochastic simulations and first-passage analysis: add physiological noise (transient sleep fragmentation events, sporadic aggregate-seeding bursts, transient vascular/glymphatic perturbations) and run Monte Carlo ensembles to compute collapse probability/time-to-collapse distributions for SNc- vs VTA-like parameter sets across lifespans that incorporate age-dependent decline in Phi_sleep. Metrics: probability of somatic energetic collapse by age, mean first-passage time, sensitivity to sleep-fragmentation frequency/amplitude.

6) Sensitivity & intervention quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) to rank which parameters (sleep flux amplitude, aggregate nucleation rate, extracellular proteolysis, varicosity density) most influence tipping. Simulate interventions: (a) modest restoration of nocturnal glymphatic flux (e.g., increase Phi_sleep by X%), (b) reduction of extracellular aggregation nucleation (pharmacological chaperones), (c) reducing local release (lower firing/fewer varicosities), and compute effect sizes required to avert tipping or rescue post-collapse. Compare required magnitudes to published intervention effect sizes where available.

7) Cross-validation with epidemiology and pathology: compare model-predicted sensitivity to sleep fragmentation and timing of collapse with reported epidemiological associations (e.g., RBD to PD conversion rates) and post-mortem measures of extracellular α‑synuclein burden and nigral loss where data exist. Produce experimentally falsifiable thresholds (e.g., fraction reduction in nocturnal clearance predicted to increase collapse probability by Y%).

8) Code and data release: publish curated parameter tables, PDE solver code, bifurcation/analysis notebooks, and a lightweight web tool that lets experimentalists input measured sleep/glymphatic metrics and anatomical densities to compute 'distance-to-glymphatic-tipping' for a region.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data sparsity on glymphatic metrics in SNc: high-resolution, region-specific measures of glymphatic flux and interstitial clearance for midbrain (SNc vs VTA), especially in humans, are limited. We will mitigate by using cross-species priors, conservative uncertainty bands, and sensitivity analyses; focus on qualitative phase-structure rather than precise numeric thresholds.

2) Simplified extracellular chemistry: extracellular aggregation and oxidative chemistry are complex (multiple species, membrane interactions). The model intentionally reduces these to minimal cooperative kinetics that capture bistability; different kinetic kernels may shift quantitative results. We will test multiple aggregation/clearance kernels to ensure robustness of the main topological conclusion.

3) Coupling scales: mapping extracellular concentration fields to somatic mitochondrial damage involves assumptions about spatial averaging and effective coupling; empirical calibration is indirect. We will explore alternate coupling kernels (distance weighting, varicosity-driven coupling) and assess sensitivity.

4) Overlap with astrocytic mechanisms: astrocytes participate in interstitial clearance and ROS detoxification; while conceptually distinct from an astrocyte-buffering model, the mechanisms interact. Positive results will motivate integrated astrocyte–glymphatic follow-ups; negative results may reflect missing astrocytic detail rather than absence of effect.

5) Translational interpretation: predicted effect sizes to avert tipping (e.g., percent increase in glymphatic flux) may be challenging to achieve clinically. The project aims to quantify required magnitudes to inform realistic experimental/interventional priorities rather than claim immediate therapeutic feasibility.

6) Alternative explanations: PD is multifactorial; glymphatic impairment may be one of several converging risk factors. The model will therefore be careful to present glymphatic-driven tipping as a plausible, testable contributor, and will propose discriminative predictions (linking measured sleep metrics to local extracellular accumulation and energetic risk) to differentiate it from purely cell-autonomous hypotheses.

Name: trophic_retrograde_tipping
Title: Retrograde Trophic-Transport Tipping: How Target-Derived Growth-Factor Competition and Transport Limits Produce an Irreversible Survival Bifurcation in Dopaminergic Neurons
Short Hypothesis: Long-range retrograde trophic signaling (e.g., GDNF/BDNF) from striatal target fields to nigral somata is finite and must be shared among many terminals; cooperative receptor signaling and transport delays create a load-dependent saddle-node bifurcation in a neurons survival axis. SNc neurons, with vastly larger terminal fields and greater dependency on retrograde support, sit inside a bistable band where stochastic drops in trophic flux or transport efficacy cause terminal loss that irreversibly reduces trophic uptake (hysteresis), driving energetic/structural collapse. This mechanism explains selectivity, slow prodrome, and practical irreversibility, and is testable using published terminal-field reconstructions, measured trophic secretion/uptake kinetics, and transport rates without new wet-lab work.
Related Work: Empirical literature shows that dopaminergic neuron survival depends on target-derived neurotrophic factors (GDNF, BDNF) delivered retrogradely; retrograde transport deficits and reduced trophic signaling have been implicated in Parkinsons disease. Anatomical studies quantify enormous nigrostriatal arborization in SNc compared to VTA. Prior computational proposals have focused on cell-autonomous energetic load, mitochondrial dynamics, proteostasis, astrocytic buffering, or axonal percolation of mitochondrial failure. Few models explicitly treat target-derived trophic supply, receptor-cooperative survival signaling, and retrograde transport as the primary control parameter. This proposal differs by (i) centering retrograde trophic flux and its finite, spatially-distributed supply and uptake as the explicit bifurcation driver, (ii) including cooperative receptor/ signaling amplification (Hill kinetics) and transport delays that generate saddle-node bistability and hysteresis, and (iii) analyzing competition among neurons for limited trophic resources in the target field (a population-selection effect). Unlike simple energetic-load models, trophic-transport tipping identifies distinct intervention levers (increase target secretion, improve transport efficiency, or reduce terminal demand) and explains why late supplementation often fails unless anatomically implausible terminal restoration occurs.
Abstract: Selective degeneration of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons in Parkinsons disease contrasts with relative preservation of neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons. While mitochondrial stress, calcium burden, and synucleinopathy have been implicated, a parsimonious explanation linking long-term resilience to target-derived trophic support is underexplored. We propose a minimal, literature-grounded dynamical theory: striatal-derived trophic factors (e.g., GDNF/BDNF) are produced at finite rates, taken up at numerous dopaminergic varicosities, and conveyed retrogradely to the soma via transport processes with limited capacity. Receptor-mediated survival signaling is cooperative, so somatic signaling and maintenance of axonal terminals depend nonlinearly on the aggregate trophic flux returning to the soma. Combining published data on terminal-field size and density, trophic secretion and receptor kinetics, and axonal transport velocities, we show analytically and numerically that increasing terminal-field load or decreasing trophic flux/transport produces a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation: healthy and atrophied steady states coexist over a band of effective loads. SNc neurons, having huge terminal fields and long transport times, map inside this bistable band where physiologic noise or modest declines in trophic supply (aging, target pathology) can stochastically drive them across the separatrix into a collapsed attractor with lost terminals and suppressed retrograde signaling. Hysteresis renders rescue by later trophic augmentation ineffective unless terminal field is anatomically restored. The theory unifies selective vulnerability, long prodromal phases, and practical irreversibility as consequences of geometric distance from a trophic tipping point and yields quantitative, testable predictions about required changes in trophic production or transport efficiency to delay or reverse collapse. All model code, curated parameter priors from the literature, and mapping scripts will be released to enable experimental follow-up.
Experiments: 1) Literature assembly and priors: compile published quantitative data and ranges for striatal trophic-factor (GDNF/BDNF) secretion rates, extracellular diffusion and degradation constants, receptor binding/unbinding/activation kinetics, trophic uptake per varicosity, receptor cooperativity exponents (Hill coefficients), retrograde transport velocities and capacity limits, terminal-field metrics (total varicosity count, spatial distribution) for SNc and VTA neurons, and age-associated declines in trophic production or transport. Build probabilistic priors for each parameter from meta-analysis of the literature.

2) Minimal two-compartment ODE model (single-neuron): construct a compact dynamical model with variables: T_soma (somatic survival signaling level, proportional to retrograde trophic flux arriving at soma) and A_term (effective preserved axonal terminal mass/number). Core equations: dA/dt = growth_biogenesis(T_soma) - loss_due_to_energy_demand(A,aging); dT_soma/dt = transport_input(A,field_conc) * transport_efficiency - decay(T_soma). Include cooperative dependence of growth_biogenesis on T_soma (e.g., Hill function) and saturating transport flux proportional to terminal uptake and constrained by retrograde capacity and distance-dependent delay. Analyze steady states and show existence of saddle-node folds by continuation (AUTO/pyDSTool).

3) Spatial target-field model: implement a spatial model of the striatal trophic-field where multiple neurons' terminals consume locally secreted trophic factor. Model secretion as distributed sources, diffusion/decay in extracellular space, and uptake as sink terms proportional to local varicosity density. Couple uptake to retrograde transport capacity (per neuron) with explicit transport delay/attenuation depending on arbor length. Simulate multiple neurons competing for shared trophic resources and observe selection dynamics—the emergence of a subpopulation that maintains signaling vs those that collapse.

4) Stochastic simulations and first-passage analysis: add physiological noise (transient reductions in target secretion, transport failure events, random terminal loss) and run ensembles to compute collapse probability and first-passage times for SNc- and VTA-like parameter draws from priors. Metrics: probability of somatic signaling falling below maintenance threshold by age, distribution of times-to-collapse, fraction of terminals lost at collapse, and sensitivity to noise amplitude.

5) Sensitivity and uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) across the assembled priors to rank which parameters (total trophic production, diffusion/decay, receptor cooperativity, transport efficiency, total varicosity count) most influence bifurcation location, hysteresis width, and collapse probability. Produce confidence bands for critical parameter thresholds.

6) Mapping to published experimental outcomes: compare model predictions to literature reports where exogenous trophic delivery (e.g., GDNF infusions, gene therapy) had limited or variable rescue: map reported effect sizes (increase in local trophic concentration or effective retrograde flux) to model-predicted ability to avert collapse or rescue after collapse. Test whether reported failures are consistent with hysteresis and anatomical constraints predicted by the model.

7) Intervention simulations and feasibility analysis: quantify required intervention magnitudes to (a) prevent tipping (e.g., percent increase in striatal trophic secretion, percent improvement in retrograde transport), and (b) rescue post-collapse (amount of terminal restoration required). Simulate combinations (moderate increase in secretion + modest transport enhancement) to find feasible synergistic strategies. Report effect sizes relative to published gene-therapy/infusion study magnitudes.

8) Public release: publish all curated parameter tables, model code (Python, pyDSTool/AUTO notebooks), and an interactive mapping tool allowing experimentalists to input measured terminal counts or trophic concentrations and obtain a 'distance-to-tipping' estimate with uncertainty.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data gaps and variability: quantitative in vivo measures of GDNF/BDNF secretion rates, extracellular concentrations, and receptor cooperativity in adult human striatum are sparse and heterogeneous across studies/species. Mitigation: use meta-analytic priors, cross-species scaling, and broad uncertainty bands; focus on qualitative bifurcation geometry and ranking of intervention levers rather than precise numeric thresholds.

2) Model simplifications: the model abstracts many molecular details (intracellular survival pathways, receptor trafficking, local astrocytic modulation of trophic availability). The goal is to test plausibility and topological consequences (bistability/hysteresis) of finite retrograde trophic flux; molecular detail can be layered later if warranted.

3) Competition modeling assumptions: representing multi-neuron competition for a shared trophic pool assumes spatial mixing and steady secretion patterns that may not hold in vivo. We will test robustness across spatial layouts (clustered vs diffuse terminals) and secretion heterogeneity.

4) Causality and multifactorial disease: trophic deficit is likely one of multiple interacting contributors to PD (proteostatic stress, mitochondrial failure, alpha-synuclein spread). This model does not exclude other mechanisms but proposes trophic-transport tipping as a parsimonious, testable contributor that yields distinct intervention predictions (e.g., why late trophic augmentation may fail).

5) Translational interpretation: interventions that increase trophic supply or restore terminals may be technically challenging; the model quantifies required magnitudes to inform experimental strategy but does not address clinical safety or delivery feasibility.

6) Identifiability and parameter sloppiness: different parameter combinations could produce similar observed collapse behavior, complicating inference from limited data. We will emphasize robust qualitative predictions, perform identifiability analysis, and present ranges of intervention effect sizes rather than single-point estimates.

Name: nad_redox_tipping
Title: Redox Reserve Tipping: NAD+/NADH Decline as a Topological Driver of Selective Dopaminergic Neuron Failure
Short Hypothesis: Age- and activity-dependent decline in neuronal NAD+ redox reserve (N) couples nonlinearly to mitochondrial maintenance and biogenesis (M) via NAD+-dependent signaling (e.g., sirtuins/PGC-1α), creating a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation. High axonal/cellular demand (A,C) in SNc dopaminergic neurons places them inside a narrow bistable band where physiological noise or modest NAD+ depletion can trigger irreversible energetic collapse; VTA neurons remain in a monostable safe regime. This hypothesis is directly testable using published metabolomics, expression, and physiological summary data plus new minimal dynamical modeling and bifurcation/stochastic analysis—no new wet-lab data required.
Related Work: Empirical literature documents (i) NAD+ decline with age and its role in mitochondrial homeostasis via sirtuin/PGC-1α pathways; (ii) Pissadaki & Bolam-style energetic arguments linking large axonal arbors and pacemaking calcium to elevated metabolic demand in SNc; (iii) models of mitochondrial bistability and tipping driven by load, proteostatic limits, or mtDNA dynamics. What is missing is a focused topological theory placing the NAD+/NADH redox couple—the cell's core metabolic currency—at the center of the bifurcation geometry. Prior work treats NAD+ largely as a therapeutic target (nicotinamide precursors) or as part of biochemical cascades; we will instead ask whether realistic, literature-supported rates of NAD+ decline and NAD+-dependent cooperative mitochondrial recovery generically produce saddle-node folds that separate SNc vs VTA vulnerability. This differs from past models by (a) elevating redox reserve as the primary slow variable coupled to mitochondrial biogenesis control, (b) using published metabolite and enzyme-expression summaries to map cell types into phase space, and (c) deriving quantitative predictions about required NAD-restorative effect sizes (e.g., nicotinamide riboside dosing equivalents) to move neurons out of bistability.
Abstract: Selective degeneration of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons in Parkinsons disease remains poorly explained despite implicating axonal load, calcium stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, and proteostatic failure. We propose a minimal, literature-grounded dynamical theory: the NAD+/NADH redox reserve (N) and mitochondrial functional mass (M) form a coupled two-variable system whose nonlinear interactions produce a load-dependent saddle-node bifurcation. NAD+ drives sirtuin-dependent activation of mitochondrial biogenesis (PGC-1α axis) and is consumed by energetic and repair processes; conversely, mitochondrial function sustains NAD+ regeneration. High structural (axon arbor A) and ionic (calcium pacemaking C) demand increases NAD+ consumption and pushes the system toward a fold bifurcation. We will assemble published metabolomic, transcriptomic (NAMPT, SIRT, PGC-1α), and physiological summary statistics to parameterize plausible SNc- and VTA-like ensembles. Deterministic bifurcation analysis will identify bistable bands and hysteresis; stochastic simulations will compute first-passage collapse probabilities under physiologically plausible NAD+ decline and transient insults. We predict SNc neurons map inside a narrow bistable band where modest NAD+ depletion or transient increased demand triggers irreversible-like collapse, whereas VTA neurons remain in a deep monostable basin. The model yields concrete, testable predictions: how much increase in NAD+ synthesis/precursors, sirtuin activation, or modest firing-rate reduction is required to avert tipping, and whether timing of NAD-restorative therapy matters given hysteresis. All code and curated parameter ensembles will be published to enable direct mapping of new metabolomic or expression data onto a 'distance-to-redox-tipping' metric.
Experiments: 1) Literature meta-analysis and priors: curate published quantitative measures and summary statistics: baseline NAD+/NADH ratios and NAD+ pool sizes in brain and midbrain (rodent, primate, human where available); age-related decline rates of NAD+; expression/activity ranges for NAMPT, NMNAT, SIRT1/3, PGC-1α; energetic cost-per-spike and calcium-related NAD+ consumption proxies from electrophysiology and bioenergetics studies; axonal arbor effective load metrics for SNc vs VTA from reconstructions. Build probabilistic priors for all model parameters.

2) Minimal two-variable dynamical model: formulate a compact ODE system: dN/dt = synthesis(NAMPT_activity) - consumption(Demand(A,C,G)) + regeneration_from_mito(M) - degradation; dM/dt = biogenesis_gain * f_sirtuin(N)*M^alpha - damage_rate(Demand,ROS)*M. Include cooperative dependence of mitochondrial biogenesis on NAD+-dependent signaling (e.g., Hill-type f_sirtuin(N)) to allow saddle-node geometry. Keep model parsimonious so parameters are interpretable and mappable to literature summaries.

3) Deterministic bifurcation analysis: perform continuation (AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont) across axes: effective load (combined A and C), baseline NAD+ synthesis capacity (proxy for NAMPT expression/activity), and cooperativity exponent alpha. Locate saddle-node folds, bistability regions, separatrix geometry, and hysteresis width. Produce phase diagrams showing SNc vs VTA mapping given literature-derived parameter ensembles.

4) Stochastic simulations and first-passage analysis: add physiologically plausible noise (transient NAD+ depletion events, mitochondrial insults, bursts of calcium) and run ensemble stochastic simulations to compute collapse probability, mean first-passage times, and distribution under age-like NAD+ decline trajectories. Evaluate sensitivity of collapse probability to noise amplitude and timing (e.g., midlife NAD+ dips).

5) Mapping neurons to phase space: using curated expression and metabolomic summaries, map SNc and VTA parameter ensembles (NAMPT activity, baseline N, A, C) into model parameter space to estimate empirical distance-to-tipping and probability of being in bistable band. Use Bayesian propagation of measurement uncertainty to produce credible intervals for mapping.

6) Sensitivity and intervention quantification: global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) to rank which biological levers (increasing NAMPT activity, providing NAD+ precursors matching specific effect sizes, activating sirtuins, decreasing firing rate) most efficiently move SNc ensembles out of bistability. Simulate in silico interventions with literature-derived effect-size priors (e.g., reported NAD+ increase after NR or NMN dosing in animal studies) to quantify expected reduction in collapse probability and required dosing-equivalents to delay tipping by target years.

7) Robustness checks and alternative mechanisms: test model variants (linear vs cooperative biogenesis, including explicit NADH shuttle kinetics, coupling to proteostasis/alpha-synuclein as additive damage) to assess whether the NAD+-centered bistability is robust across mechanistic choices. Compare to published results on NAD+-boosting neuroprotection to evaluate qualitative agreement.

8) Public release and mapping tool: release all curated datasets, parameter priors, model code, and an interactive notebook/tool allowing experimentalists to input measured NAD+ or NAMPT values to compute model-based distance-to-tipping with uncertainty.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Clarity and testability: The core hypothesis is intentionally sharp: NAD+ redox reserve (N) coupled to mitochondrial mass (M) can produce saddle-node bistability under realistic loads. This is directly testable with only published metabolomics, enzyme expression data, and modeling/simulation. If region-specific NAD+ measurements are absent, proxies (NAMPT/SIRT expression, metabolomic whole-midbrain measures) will be used with explicit uncertainty propagation.

2) Novelty: While NAD+ biology and nicotinamide-based interventions are well-studied, positioning NAD+ as the central slow control variable creating topological tipping in neuronal phase space (and mapping SNc vs VTA vulnerability via literature-derived priors) is novel relative to prior energetic, proteostatic, and mtDNA-focused tipping models. To ensure novelty, we will cite and compare directly to existing mitochondrial-bistability and arbor-topology models and emphasize distinctive predictions (e.g., precise effect sizes for NAD-restoration, timing-dependence due to hysteresis).

3) Feasibility for a small computational lab: The proposal requires literature curation, modest ODE modeling, bifurcation analysis, stochastic simulation, and sensitivity quantification—entirely feasible with standard computational resources (Python, NumPy/SciPy, pyDSTool/AUTO, SALib). No wet-lab or proprietary data are needed. The main time demands are careful meta-analysis and parameter prior construction.

4) Strictly computational experiments: All proposed steps are computational: meta-analysis of published metabolomic and expression data, minimal dynamical model specification, deterministic continuation, stochastic ensemble simulations, and uncertainty/sensitivity analyses. No new experiments or proprietary datasets are required.

5) Name, title, abstract coherence: The short name 'nad_redox_tipping', title, and abstract were crafted to be concise and clearly reflect the redox-centered hypothesis and topological tipping perspective.

6) Data gaps & mitigations: Region- and cell-type-resolved NAD+ pool measurements in human SNc vs VTA may be sparse. Mitigation strategy: (a) use multiple proxy measurements (NAMPT/NMNAT, SIRT expression, bulk metabolomics), (b) apply hierarchical Bayesian priors and wide uncertainty bands, (c) perform sensitivity analyses to identify which measurements most reduce uncertainty and recommend specific targeted assays for collaborators.

7) Modeling simplifications: The simple two-variable model abstracts detailed NADH shuttle kinetics, compartmentalization (soma vs axon), and interacting mechanisms (proteostasis, mtDNA). To reduce risk of overclaiming, we will emphasize topological claims (existence of bistability, hysteresis, dependence on redox synthesis) and validate robustness across several plausible model variants (add compartmental NAD pools, explicit NADH shuttles, or additional damage terms).

8) Parameter identifiability & sloppiness: Compact nonlinear models can be 'sloppy' with non-identifiable parameter combinations. We'll use structural sensitivity (bifurcation geometry) rather than point estimates, perform global sensitivity, and report credible effect-size intervals for intervention predictions instead of single-point dosing claims.

9) Next-step plan if results are weak: If literature priors show NAD+ dynamics cannot plausibly create folds under any reasonable cooperativity, we will (a) explore combined mechanisms where NAD+ interacts with proteostatic allocation or mtDNA dynamics to produce multi-mechanism bifurcations, (b) identify which empirical measurements (e.g., direct NAD+ pools in SNc) would most decisively test the hypothesis, and (c) publish null/constraint results to guide experimentalists on feasibility of NAD+-centric therapies.

Name: pareto_lifehistory_tipping
Title: Pareto Frontier of Dopaminergic Design: Life-History Trade-offs Create a Fragility Edge Explaining SNc Vulnerability
Short Hypothesis: Dopaminergic neuron morphologies and physiology result from multi-objective evolutionary optimization (trade-offs between broadcast reach, signaling reliability, and metabolic cost). SNc neurons occupy Pareto-optimal points that maximize population-level broadcast/coverage at the expense of energetic margin; aging-driven reductions in mitochondrial capacity or clearance shift these optimized designs across a topological bifurcation (saddle-node) into an irreversible collapsed state. Mapping published morphologies, electrophysiology, and metabolic data onto a Pareto front plus a minimal energetic dynamical model will explain why SNc—but not VTA—neurons are both highly optimized for function and catastrophically fragile late in life. This framing leverages only published datasets and in silico optimization/analysis and is the most direct way to link evolutionary design pressures to observed selective vulnerability without requiring new experiments.
Related Work: Empirical and modeling work has implicated axonal arbor size and pacemaking calcium in SNc vulnerability (Pissadaki & Bolam 2013; Surmeier lab), and several recent theoretical models demonstrate how nonlinear mitochondrial dynamics produce bistable energetic collapse. Other proposals considered percolation on arbors, proteostatic allocation, mtDNA dynamics, astrocytic buffering, and control-loop maladaptation. A related 'allometric tipping' proposal used scaling laws to predict age-of-onset. What is novel here is (i) an explicit multi-objective optimization framing—using Pareto/frontier analysis and evolutionary life-history constraints—to explain why SNc neurons evolved to sit near a fragile design edge, (ii) a quantitative pipeline that maps published morphological and physiological measurements onto objective axes and computes distance-to-frontier and distance-to-tipping simultaneously, and (iii) cross-species life-history integration (lifespan vs design trade-offs) to explain vulnerability differences. This differs from prior work by linking functional optimization (why these designs exist) directly to topological tipping (why they fail) rather than treating anatomy and failure as separate facts.
Abstract: Why do substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons die in Parkinson's disease while neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons survive? We propose that SNc neurons are the product of evolutionary multi-objective optimization: maximizing dopamine broadcast reach and release reliability across the striatum while minimizing wiring/maintenance cost. These competing objectives place SNc neurons near the Pareto front of feasible designs, i.e., at high functional payoff but with low energetic margin. We hypothesize that aging-related declines (mitochondrial capacity, proteostatic flux) shift the biophysical parameters of these optimal designs across a saddle-node bifurcation, creating a bistable regime where physiological fluctuations can produce irreversible energetic collapse. To test this we will (1) assemble published single-neuron reconstructions, varicosity counts, firing/pacemaking statistics, and metabolic summaries (mitochondrial density, turnover estimates) for SNc and VTA across species; (2) define interpretable objective functions—coverage (effective territory/varicosity reach), signal fidelity (release reliability per unit cost), and metabolic cost (energy per signal) grounded in Pissadaki & Bolam-style energetics and electrophysiology summaries; (3) run multi-objective evolutionary algorithms to compute Pareto fronts in design parameter space (axon length, varicosity density, baseline firing, calcium load) under physiological constraints; (4) map real neurons onto this front, measure Pareto distance and which trade-offs they exploit; (5) couple the design coordinates to a minimal two-variable energetic dynamical model (mitochondrial capacity M and energetic reserve E) known to exhibit a saddle-node fold, and study how aging-like parameter drifts move Pareto-optimal designs across bifurcation boundaries; (6) perform stochastic simulations to compute first-passage collapse probabilities; and (7) explore cross-species life-history predictions (longer-lived species should favor safer designs or earlier compensatory changes). The result will be a testable, quantitative theory that unifies why SNc neurons were 'designed' for high function yet sit precariously close to a topological tipping point, yielding concrete predictions about which measurable design axes (e.g., varicosity per unit length, firing duty cycle) most determine vulnerability and how modest interventions shift distance-to-tipping.
Experiments: 1) Data assembly and harmonization: compile published datasets and summary statistics for single-neuron reconstructions (axon length, branch order, varicosity counts/distributions) for SNc and VTA across mouse/rat/primate/human where available; electrophysiological parameters (firing rate, burst statistics, calcium channel expression proxies); mitochondrial metrics (density, volume fraction, turnover/mitophagy rates); and species life-history data (lifespan, metabolic rate). Reconcile units and create unified design-parameter vectors with uncertainty ranges.

2) Define objective functions grounded in literature: (a) Coverage: effective striatal area reached per neuron ~ function(axon length, branching, varicosity density) calibrated to anatomical reconstructions; (b) Signaling reliability: expected released dopamine per unit time and per-target reliability from firing statistics and varicosity counts; (c) Metabolic cost: energetic expenditure per unit time estimated from axonal maintenance + firing/calcium handling using Pissadaki & Bolam-derived formulas adjusted by published ATP cost-per-spike. Validate forms against published energetic estimates.

3) Compute Pareto fronts via multi-objective optimization: run evolutionary multi-objective algorithms (NSGA-II or MOEA) across biologically feasible parameter ranges (axon length, varicosity density, baseline firing, calcium load, mitochondrial density) to generate Pareto-optimal frontiers. Characterize the geometry of the front (convexity, trade-off slopes, density of solutions) and identify clustered solution families.

4) Map empirical neurons to design space: project assembled empirical reconstructions and physiology summaries onto the design parameter space; compute each neuron's Pareto distance (how close to the front) and which objectives it prioritizes. Statistically compare distributions for SNc vs VTA neurons (e.g., Mann-Whitney tests for Pareto distance; kernel density estimates for objective loadings).

5) Coupling to energetic dynamical tipping model: implement a minimal two-variable ODE model (M: mitochondrial functional capacity; E: energetic reserve) with cooperative biogenesis and load-dependent damage terms that produce saddle-node bifurcations. Map design parameters (axon/varicosity/firing/calcium) into the model's effective demand/load parameter using literature-derived scalings. Calibrate model parameter ranges to published mitochondrial turnover and energetic production estimates.

6) Bifurcation and phase-space analysis: perform deterministic continuation across load and mitochondrial-capacity axes (AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont) to locate saddle-node folds and bistable bands. For each Pareto-optimal and empirical design point, compute distance-to-fold (delta parameter) and basin depth metrics. Visualize Pareto front overlayed on bifurcation phase-diagrams to show how optimal designs align with dangerous regions.

7) Stochastic lifespan simulation and first-passage analysis: simulate stochastic perturbations (transient mitochondrial insults, production/clearance fluctuations) and age-dependent decline in mitochondrial capacity across ensembles of design points (empirical and Pareto samples) to compute first-passage times to energetic collapse, collapse probability by age, and distribution differences between SNc and VTA ensembles. Use metrics: median time-to-collapse, hazard ratios, and ROC/AUC for Pareto distance predicting collapse.

8) Cross-species life-history analysis: embed species lifespan/repair-rate priors to test whether species with longer lifespans either occupy less extreme Pareto positions or require greater mitochondrial maintenance. Test hypothesis that life-history constraints predict observed design placements and vulnerability rankings across species.

9) Intervention and trade-off simulation: perform in silico interventions altering design axes (reduce firing by X%, decrease varicosity density, increase mitochondrial maintenance rate) to compute how much each intervention moves designs off the fragility edge and reduces collapse probability. Quantify cost-effectiveness in Pareto units (e.g., functional loss per unit reduction in collapse risk).

10) Robustness and sensitivity: perform global sensitivity (Sobol/Morris) and identifiability analyses to rank which objective formulations or parameter uncertainties most affect conclusions. Publish code, parameter priors, and data harmonization pipelines for reproducibility.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data heterogeneity and sparsity: high-quality matched morpho-physiological reconstructions (e.g., axon recon plus firing) are limited, especially in humans. Mitigation: use summary statistics, aggregate across species with appropriate scaling, propagate uncertainty, and emphasize qualitative agreement and ranking rather than exact thresholds.

2) Choice of objectives: conclusions depend on chosen objective functions (how we formalize coverage, reliability, cost). We will ground objective forms in published biophysical estimates, test alternative formulations, and report which choices change qualitative outcomes.

3) Mapping from design variables to dynamical model: linking morphology/physiology to the energetic model requires scaling assumptions (e.g., how varicosity density maps to ATP demand). Results could be sensitive to these scalings; we will use literature priors, Bayesian propagation of uncertainty, and sensitivity checks.

4) Evolutionary interpretation caveats: projecting optimization as evidence of evolutionary selection involves assumptions (fitness proxies, trade-off weights) that may be speculative. We frame evolutionary language as a hypothesis-generating explanation for observed design placement, not definitive proof; cross-species life-history tests help constrain plausibility.

5) Simplification of failure mechanisms: the energetic dynamical model is minimal and abstracts other molecular contributors (alpha-synuclein aggregation, immune effects). The project aims to show sufficiency of a Pareto-design + energetic tipping story; integrating other mechanisms is left for follow-up work.

6) Computational limits and identifiability: multi-objective optimization and ensemble stochastic simulations can be computationally intensive and some parameter combinations may be sloppy. We will use efficient algorithms (NSGA-II, surrogate modeling), moderate dimensional reductions, and present uncertainty intervals rather than overconfident point claims.

Name: sequence_dependent_multihit_tipping
Title: Path-Dependent Multihit Tipping: How the Order of Subtle Stressors Drives Irreversible Neuronal Collapse in Parkinson's Disease
Short Hypothesis: The joint action of multiple moderate stressors (e.g., sleep fragmentation/glymphatic decline, transient inflammation, increased calcium load, proteostatic burden, mild mitochondrial loss) can produce qualitatively different outcomes depending on their temporal ordering: early hits that reconfigure slow control variables (proteostatic capacity, mitochondrial reserve, NAD+ redox) open vulnerability windows that make later hits far more likely to trigger a saddle-node collapse. Thus, selective SNc vulnerability and variable prodromal timing reflect path-dependent trajectories through neuronal phase space rather than only aggregate burden. This question is best addressed computationally by combining published effect-size estimates and time-course data with minimal dynamical models and stochastic ensembles to identify sequence-sensitive dangerous orders and optimal timing for interventions.
Related Work: Many prior computational and conceptual studies have shown that neuronal energetic systems can be bistable (saddle-node folds) and that factors such as axonal load, calcium pacemaking, mitochondrial dynamics, proteostatic allocation, mtDNA clonal expansion, glial buffering, and vascular limits influence vulnerability. Empirical literature documents the variety of subtle, age-dependent insults (sleep loss, inflammation, mitochondrial decline, -synuclein seeding) associated with PD. However, existing models largely study single dominant drivers or simultaneous parameter shifts; they do not systematically study the nonlinear, path-dependent interaction between multiple time-varying stressors. This proposal differs by explicitly asking whether the temporal sequence of plausible, literature-grounded insults qualitatively alters collapse probability, timing, and hysteresis geometry — a nontrivial, mechanistic question because slow variables and hysteresis can render order-of-events decisive. It extends prior bistability and tipping-point work by embedding realistic temporally structured perturbations, performing sequence-space exploration, and deriving control-theoretic intervention timing recommendations grounded in published effect sizes.
Abstract: Parkinson's disease features a long, variable prodrome and then a relatively rapid, often irreversible loss of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons. Multiple modest insults — sleep fragmentation, low-level neuroinflammation, cumulative mitochondrial decline, increased calcium-driven demand, impaired proteostasis, and extracellular aggregate seeding — are implicated in PD, but it is unclear why their combinations produce highly variable, often abrupt outcomes. We propose that path dependence in neuronal phase space, shaped by slow control variables and hysteresis, makes the order and timing of subthreshold stressors critical: early perturbations that reduce slow reserves (mitochondrial capacity, proteostatic flux, redox pools) reposition the system nearer a saddle-node fold, so later, otherwise innocuous insults produce irreversible collapse. To test this, we will build a compact, literature-anchored dynamical model (few slow variables: mitochondrial functional mass M, proteostatic reserve P, aggregate burden A, redox reserve N, plus a fast energetic reserve E) whose nonlinearities admit saddle-node bifurcations and hysteresis. Using published time-course and effect-size priors for representative stressors (sleep/glymphatic decline, low-grade inflammation, L-type calcium upregulation, alpha-synuclein seeding, NAD+ decline), we will exhaustively sample sequence space, run stochastic ensembles, and compute first-passage statistics and basin geometries. We will identify 'high-risk sequences' (orders and timing windows that greatly increase collapse probability), quantify how much earlier interventions need to be applied to be effective, and derive robust early-warning temporal biomarkers. All inputs (effect-size priors) will come from published studies; analyses will combine deterministic continuation, stochastic simulation, global sensitivity, and optimal-control computations to produce falsifiable, actionable predictions about which early stressors are most dangerous and when to intervene. Code and curated parameter ensembles will be released to enable experimental mapping of specific cohorts onto a sequence-sensitive 'distance-to-tipping' metric.
Experiments: 1) Literature meta-analysis and priors: systematically assemble quantitative published effect-size ranges and, where available, time-course shapes for representative stressors: (a) sleep/glymphatic flux decline (magnitude/time in aging and RBD), (b) chronic low-grade inflammation markers (cytokine levels and temporal profiles), (c) mild mitochondrial capacity decline (mtDNA deletion accumulation/oxidative phosphorylation decline rates), (d) L-type calcium channel upregulation and pacemaking calcium load changes with age, (e) proteostatic flux decline (autophagy/proteasome maximal flux changes), and (f) extracellular -synuclein seeding kinetics. Convert these into probabilistic priors (distributions over amplitude, timescale, onset age) with documented citations and uncertainty bands.

2) Minimal multi-variable dynamical model: construct a parsimonious ODE/SDE model with interpretable slow variables (M: mitochondrial functional mass; P: proteostatic clearance capacity; N: redox reserve proxy) and state variables for aggregate burden A and energetic reserve E (fast). Include mechanistic couplings grounded in literature: demand increases with pacemaking and axonal load, aggregates increase mitochondrial damage and proteostatic drain, NAD+ drives mitochondrial biogenesis, proteostatic flux is finite and shared, and cooperative mitochondrial recovery allows saddle-node folds. Specify how each external stressor applies as a time-dependent modulation to one or more parameters (e.g., sleep decline reduces extracellular clearance rates increasing effective aggregate production; inflammation increases mitochondrial damage rate). Implement both deterministic and stochastic (noise in production/insult events) versions.

3) Deterministic bifurcation analysis: for static parameter shifts reproduce known saddle-node geometry; then compute how slow-variable basins change under sustained perturbations. Use continuation tools (AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont) to map folds as functions of canonical stressor amplitudes, and to identify how slow-variable shifts (e.g., lowered P or N) move the separatrix and hysteresis width.

4) Sequence-space exploration (in silico multihit experiments): define a discrete set of representative stressor events (S={sleep decline, inflammation, calcium increase, mitochondrial decline, proteostatic drop, seeding pulse}). For each permutation and selected timings (e.g., early, mid, late life relative to slow decline trajectories) simulate large stochastic ensembles (Monte Carlo) using literature-derived priors to compute collapse probability, distribution of first-passage times, and typical trajectories. Quantify fold-change in collapse risk versus simultaneous application and versus baseline single-hit application.

5) Sensitivity and uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol indices) across priors to rank which stressors and which timing windows most strongly influence sequence sensitivity and collapse probability. Identify whether particular stressors act as 'primers' (sensitizers that enlarge vulnerability for later hits).

6) Early-warning and transient biomarker analysis: analyze trajectory statistics (variance, autocorrelation, recovery rates—critical slowing down metrics) during and after early hits to identify temporal biomarkers that best predict later collapse given sequence context. Test predictive power (ROC curves) of these metrics when only short-term longitudinal measurements (published electrophysiology or imaging summary statistics) are available.

7) Optimal timing and control interventions: formulate and solve optimal-control problems to compute minimal interventions (timing, magnitude, target variable: boost P, restore sleep flux, reduce calcium entry, NAD+ supplementation) required at different sequence stages to avoid tipping with high probability. Compare effect sizes to published intervention ranges (e.g., reported NAD+ increases from NR/NMN dosing, anti-inflammatory effect sizes) to assess practical feasibility.

8) Mapping to empirical studies and falsification tests: use published cohort-level longitudinal findings (e.g., RBD conversion rates, inflammation biomarker cohorts, interventions with reported effect sizes) to check whether identified high-risk sequences and timing windows align with epidemiological observations. Propose falsifiable cohort-level predictions (e.g., individuals with early sleep fragmentation followed by chronic inflammation have X-fold higher modeled collapse probability) and list published datasets to test these claims.

9) Reproducible release: publish all curated priors, model code, continuation notebooks, stochastic simulation scripts, and analysis pipelines; include convenience functions to map new measured effect sizes/time-courses into the model to compute sequence-specific distance-to-tipping and recommended intervention timing.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty and heterogeneous literature: quantitative time-course and effect-size data for some stressors (especially human-region-resolved measures) are sparse and heterogeneous. Mitigation: explicit probabilistic priors, Monte Carlo ensembles, and reporting of credible intervals; emphasize qualitative, sequence-dependent topological conclusions that are robust across wide priors.

2) Model-structure choices: the minimal model must balance interpretability and biophysical realism; different mechanistic abstractions could alter which sequences appear most dangerous. Mitigation: test multiple plausible model variants (alternate coupling functions, additional slow variables), and report robust features across model families.

3) Non-identifiability and sloppiness: multivariate nonlinear models can be sloppy, with multiple parameter combinations producing similar outcomes. We will focus on bifurcation geometry and relative sequence effects rather than absolute numeric collapse times and perform identifiability/sensitivity analyses to highlight influential measurements.

4) Mapping epidemiology to single-cell collapse: population-level clinical data reflect many systemic factors; mapping cohort observations to modeled single-neuron collapse probabilities is indirect. We will propose cohort-level, testable statistical predictions (risk ratios, interaction effects) rather than claim direct causation of clinical onset.

5) Computational cost: exhaustive permutation/timing exploration with large stochastic ensembles can be computationally expensive.
