Mitigation: use surrogate models and active sampling (Gaussian-process emulators) to efficiently explore sequence space and focus full-resolution simulations on high-risk sequences.

6) Translational complexity of interventions: optimal-control-derived intervention timings and magnitudes may be challenging to implement clinically; the goal is to quantify relative leverage and timing sensitivity to inform experimental priorities, not to propose immediate therapies.

7) Confounding interacting mechanisms: our model will not include every PD-relevant process (e.g., adaptive immune responses, multi-cellular network effects) — positive results indicate plausibility and prioritize experiments to test sequence dependence; negative results narrow the set of likely sequence-sensitive mechanisms.

Name: inverse_bifurcation_inference
Title: Inferring Topological Tipping from Pathology: Inverse Bifurcation Discovery of Energetic Collapse in Parkinson's Disease
Short Hypothesis: Cross-sectional and cohort-level published pathology and biomarker statistics (age-stratified SNc neuronal counts, mtDNA deletion prevalence, -synuclein burden, imaging proxies) already contain signatures of an underlying bistable energetic system. By treating observed between-individual distributions as noisy samples from an age-dependent stochastic dynamical system and performing principled inverse inference, we can (i) determine whether bistability/hysteresis (saddle-node folds) better explains population data than monostable alternatives, (ii) estimate key topological parameters (fold locations, hysteresis width, noise amplitude), and (iii) map where SNc vs VTA populations sit in phase space. This paper uses only published datasets and modeling to test whether human/pathology data provide quantitative evidence for a tipping-point topology underlying selective vulnerability.
Related Work: Many computational models have proposed forward mechanisms producing neuronal energetic bistability (mitochondrial cooperative recovery, proteostatic allocation, axonal topology). Empirical literature provides cross-sectional and age-stratified measures: stereological SNc neuron counts vs age/PD stage, mtDNA deletion fractions in aged nigral neurons, Braak staging and -synuclein burden summaries, and imaging markers (DAT-SPECT) showing non-linear decline. Prior work has not attempted a principled inverse approach to infer dynamical topology from these population-level statistics. Our approach differs by (a) treating observed cross-sectional variability as the stationary / transient output of an age-dependent stochastic dynamical system, (b) using Fokker-Planck / likelihood-based and ABC inference to recover dynamical parameters and test for bistability and hysteresis, and (c) leveraging multiple, heterogeneous published datasets in a hierarchical framework to constrain topology rather than parameters of any single forward mechanism. This is not a trivial extension: inferring topology (existence and location of folds) from population histograms under noise and aging is a novel methodological contribution and provides empirical constraint on many forward models.
Abstract: Selective degeneration of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons in Parkinson's disease has been argued to result from load-dependent nonlinear failures (saddle-node bifurcations) in cellular energetics. Numerous mechanistic forward models show such topology is plausible, but the question remains: do existing human and animal pathology datasets actually contain evidence for bistability and hysteresis at the population level? We propose an inverse, data-driven program to answer this. We will assemble published, age-stratified summary statistics and digitized curves: stereological SNc neuronal counts by age and disease stage, proportions of respiratory-chain-deficient neurons and mtDNA deletion burdens, regional -synuclein pathology prevalence, and in vivo imaging decline trajectories (DAT-SPECT/PET) where available. We will build a minimal stochastic dynamical model of an effective neuronal energetic state x(t) (fast/slow components abstracted) whose drift depends on age-dependent decline in maintenance and a nonlinear recovery term capable of producing saddle-node folds. Using analytical stationary solutions (Fokker-Planck) where possible and time-dependent stochastic simulations otherwise, we will compute the predicted cross-sectional distributions of x at different ages. We will then perform hierarchical Bayesian inference and likelihood-free inference (ABC-SMC) to fit model topology parameters (existence & location of folds, noise amplitude, aging drift) to the assembled datasets, comparing monostable vs bistable models via Bayes factors and posterior predictive checks. We will validate by predicting independent datasets (VTA counts, different cohorts), quantify the inferred separatrix and hysteresis width, and translate these topological estimates into practical intervention effect sizes (how much increasing maintenance or reducing load would be needed to move a typical SNc neuron out of the bistable band). The work both provides an empirical test of tipping hypotheses and introduces a general methodology for inferring dynamical topology from cross-sectional biological data.
Experiments: 1) Literature synthesis and data digitization: systematic search and digitization of published age-stratified and cohort-level summaries: SNc and VTA stereological neuron counts vs age (control cohorts and PD cases), fraction of respiratory-chain-deficient neurons and mtDNA deletion metrics by age, regional -synuclein burden summaries/Braak stage prevalence by age, DAT-SPECT/PET decline curves, and any available longitudinal imaging cohorts. For each source record measurement errors, cohort size, and measurement modality to build hierarchical data inputs.

2) Minimal stochastic dynamical model family: define a compact one- or two-variable stochastic model for an effective neuronal energetic state x (or (M,E) if two variables) with drift f(x;theta,age) that includes (i) an age-dependent decline term, (ii) a nonlinear cooperative recovery term parameterized so the system can be monostable or bistable (tunable Hill/cooperativity exponent), and (iii) additive/multiplicative noise. Derive the corresponding Fokker-Planck stationary distributions for fixed-age (quasi-stationary) regimes when analytic solutions are available (e.g., one-dimensional SDE with reflecting boundaries).

3) Forward-calculation of predicted cross-sectional distributions: for given parameter sets compute predicted distributions of x at different ages: (a) analytic stationary densities (Fokker-Planck) where valid, (b) numerically solve time-dependent Fokker-Planck for age-driven drift scenarios, and (c) complement with ensemble SDE simulations for validation. Map predicted x distributions to observable quantities (neuron survival fraction, % respiratory-deficient cells, imaging signal) using literature-grounded observation models (e.g., thresholding x to survival loss, logistic mapping to DAT signal).

4) Hierarchical inference & model selection: use Bayesian inference (MCMC) where likelihoods tractable (analytical / numerically computed densities) and ABC-SMC / synthetic likelihood for cases with intractable likelihoods to infer posterior distributions over topology-relevant parameters (number/location of stable fixed points, fold positions, noise amplitude, aging rate). Fit models jointly to multiple heterogeneous datasets in a hierarchical structure that accounts for measurement bias and cohort effects. Compare model classes (monostable linear drift, monostable nonlinear, bistable saddle-node capable) using Bayes factors, WAIC, and posterior predictive checks.

5) Cross-validation & external prediction: hold out independent datasets (e.g., VTA counts, separate cohorts or imaging modalities) and test model predictive accuracy for distributions and trajectories. Evaluate whether the inferred bistable model better explains sudden nonlinearity in population declines and cohort-to-cohort variability than monostable models.

6) Synthetic identifiability and power analysis: using the assembled priors, simulate synthetic datasets under known topologies to determine what data quantity and measurement precision are required to reliably infer bistability and estimate fold positions. This will show which published data sources are informative and what future measurements would most reduce uncertainty.

7) Translate topology to intervention effect sizes: from posterior over fold locations and hysteresis width compute the minimal parameter shifts (e.g., percent increase in maintenance term or percent decrease in effective load) required to move a typical SNc neuron out of the bistable band. Translate to literature-measured intervention effect sizes (e.g., reported percent NAD+ increases, autophagy upregulation) to judge practical feasibility.

8) Sensitivity and robustness checks: perform global sensitivity analyses on priors and observation mappings, test alternative observation models (e.g., survival mapping vs continuous biomarker mapping), and report robustness of topology inference to systematic biases across studies.

9) Release reproducible pipeline: publish all digitized data, inference code, model variants, posterior samples, and interactive visualizations that let researchers input their cohort statistics to obtain inferred topology and distance-to-tipping estimates.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Heterogeneous, biased, and sparse data: published pathology and imaging studies vary in methods, cohort selection, and measurement noise. This complicates inference and may reduce identifiability of topology. Mitigation: use hierarchical models that explicitly model study-level biases, propagate uncertainty, and perform synthetic power analyses to quantify limits.

2) Cross-sectional vs longitudinal inference limits: inferring dynamics (including hysteresis) from cross-sectional snapshots requires assumptions (quasi-stationarity, similar cohorts). Results will be probabilistic and sensitive to violations. Mitigation: include any available longitudinal cohorts, perform sensitivity analyses, and be explicit about inference assumptions.

3) Model identifiability / sloppiness: multiple parametric models can reproduce similar observed distributions; inferring the qualitative topology (mono- vs bistable) is easier than precise parameter estimates. Mitigation: focus on robust topological conclusions, report credible intervals, and provide synthetic-data benchmarks showing when topology is recoverable.

4) Mapping latent dynamic variable to observables: the choice of observation model (how latent x maps to neuron counts or imaging signal) can bias conclusions. Mitigation: test multiple plausible observation mappings grounded in literature, and include mapping uncertainty in hierarchical inference.

5) Confounding population effects: cohort-level confounders (co-morbidities, medications, selection biases) can mimic nonlinearity. Mitigation: encode known covariates where available, restrict to population subsets for sensitivity checks, and interpret results cautiously.

6) Negative or inconclusive outcome possibility: it's possible published data are insufficient to support strong topological inference. This outcome is still valuable: it quantifies which measurements would be necessary to distinguish topology and guides future data collection (sample sizes, longitudinal designs, specific biomarkers).

7) Methodological complexity: performing rigorous inference (Fokker-Planck numerics, ABC, hierarchical Bayesian models) requires careful validation to avoid artifacts. We'll use multiple inference strategies, cross-validation, and open code to ensure reproducibility.

Name: membrane_repair_tipping
Title: Membrane Repair Tipping: Dopamine-driven Lipid Peroxidation and Limited Phospholipid Remodeling Create an Irreversible Energetic Collapse in Nigral Neurons
Short Hypothesis: High-density dopaminergic terminal fields and dopamine autoxidation in SNc produce a chronic flux of lipid peroxidation (LP) damage to axonal membrane. Phospholipid-remodeling (Lands cycle) and glutathione-dependent reduction provide a finite, slowly renewing membrane-repair capacity R that can be overwhelmed cooperatively: above a critical effective per-terminal LP production rate (set by varicosity density, firing, and extracellular oxidation), repair dynamics undergo a load-driven saddle-node bifurcation that generates bistability between a healthy, low-damage state and a high-damage, low-energy state. SNc neurons map inside the bistable band while VTA neurons remain monostable. Physiological noise or transient insults can stochastically push SNc trajectories across the separatrix into a membrane-damaged attractor; hysteresis prevents practical rescue unless membrane-repair capacity is increased well beyond physiologically plausible amounts. This hypothesis can be tested solely with published measurements (varicosity density, DA release/oxidation rates, lipid peroxidation kinetics, enzyme turnover/repair rates, GSH pool sizes) together with new dynamical and spatial modeling.
Related Work: Empirical literature documents selective SNc vulnerability, dense nigrostriatal arborization, autonomous pacemaking with substantial dopamine release, dopamine autoxidation and quinone formation, and evidence of lipid peroxidation and impaired antioxidant defenses in PD. Biochemically, phospholipid repair (the Lands cycle: phospholipase A2-mediated deacylation and acyltransferase re-acylation), glutathione-dependent reduction of lipid peroxides (GPx), and ferroptosis-related lipid damage pathways have been intensively studied. Prior computational proposals focused on energetic load, mitochondrial dynamics, axonal percolation, proteostatic allocation, mtDNA dynamics, glial buffering, vascular supply, trafficking resonance and other mechanisms, but none elevate membrane maintenance and phospholipid remodeling as the central slow control variable producing topological tipping. This proposal differs by (i) making membrane damage/repair the primary slow variable coupled to energetic reserve, (ii) using published lipid-peroxidation and repair kinetics plus anatomical/physiological varicosity data to quantitatively map SNc vs VTA into a bifurcation diagram, and (iii) predicting distinct intervention effect sizes (antioxidant replenishment vs boosting remodeling enzymes) that differ from purely mitochondrial or proteostatic strategies. It is not a trivial extension: membrane chemistry yields cooperative damage/repair nonlinearities and spatially distributed sources (terminals) that qualitatively change separatrix geometry and hysteresis compared to prior mechanisms.
Abstract: Dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) degenerate preferentially in Parkinson's disease while neighboring ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons are comparatively spared. Dopamine autoxidation, lipid peroxidation (LP), oxidative stress, and deficits in antioxidant and lipid remodeling pathways have been reported in PD, but a simple, quantitative mechanism explaining selective vulnerability and irreversible collapse is lacking. We propose that the balance between per-terminal LP production and cellular phospholipid-repair capacity constitutes a slow, topological control axis. Using published measurements (varicosity/axon densities, DA release and extracellular oxidation kinetics, LP chain-propagation rates, GPx/GSH dynamics, PLA2/ACSL/LPCAT enzyme kinetics and turnover), we build a minimal dynamical model coupling membrane damage D(t) and repair capacity R(t) to cellular energetic reserve E(t). Cooperativity arises because LP accelerates production of further reactive lipid species and impairs repair enzyme function, while low E reduces ATP-dependent re-acylation flux. We show analytically and numerically that increasing effective terminal load produces a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation and a bistable band: a healthy low-D/high-R attractor coexists with a pathological high-D/low-R attractor. Mapping literature-derived SNc and VTA parameter ensembles into phase space places SNc inside the bistable band with shallow energetic basins, explaining stochastic escape under physiological noise. Hysteresis renders rescue by later antioxidant therapy or modest energy boosts impractical unless repair capacity is dramatically increased. The membrane-repair tipping perspective unifies dopamine oxidation, lipid peroxidation signatures, and the practical irreversibility of late-stage degeneration, and yields quantitative, testable predictions for intervention effect sizes and biomarker thresholds. All curated priors and code will be released.
Experiments: 1) Literature curation and probabilistic priors: systematically collect published quantitative values and uncertainties for: varicosity/axon terminal density and spatial distributions for SNc and VTA (rodent/primate/human where available); per-release dopamine quantity and extracellular oxidation rates to reactive quinones and ROS; lipid peroxidation chain-initiation and propagation rates (k_init, k_propagation), lifetimes of lipid radicals, and cross-termination rates from biochemical studies; glutathione (GSH) pool sizes and GPx kinetics; phospholipase A2 (PLA2) and acyltransferase (LPCAT/ACSL) catalytic rates/turnover, ATP cost for re-acylation (Lands cycle) and their dependence on ATP/oxidative state; and reported effect sizes for antioxidant or lipid-repair enzyme manipulations in cells/animal models. Assemble these into probabilistic priors for model parameters.

2) Minimal deterministic ODE model construction: implement a compact three-variable system: dD/dt = production(D,A,f,DA_ox,ROS) + chain_propagation(D) - repair(R,E)*g(D); dR/dt = synthesis_basal - consumption_by_repair - inhibition_by_D (capture enzyme oxidation/inactivation and ATP-dependence); dE/dt = mitochondrial_production(M,E) - demand(A,f) - extra_cost_of_membrane_repair(repair_rate). Choose simple nonlinear forms that encode cooperative LP propagation (e.g., D^n term) and enzyme inactivation by D. Include saturating repair kinetics (Michaelis–Menten) dependent on enzyme availability and ATP. Parameterize functions with priors from step 1.

3) Bifurcation and phase-space analysis (deterministic): perform continuation (AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont) on key control parameters: effective terminal load (function of varicosity density A and firing/pacemaking f), baseline GSH pool / GPx capacity, and repair enzyme synthesis rate. Locate saddle-node folds, map the bistable band, compute separatrix geometry and hysteresis width, and identify critical load thresholds separating monostable and bistable regimes. Produce phase diagrams overlaying SNc and VTA parameter ensembles.

4) Stochastic simulations and first-passage analysis: add physiologically plausible noise sources (transient bursts of oxidative insults, stochastic fluctuations in firing/release, episodic stress events) and run Monte Carlo simulations (Gillespie or stochastic differential equations) for SNc- and VTA-like parameter draws. Compute metrics: probability and distribution of time-to-collapse (first-passage to high-D attractor), mean first-passage time as a function of age-like drift in repair synthesis, and how small perturbations can trigger escape from the shallow healthy basin in SNc parameter ensembles.

5) Spatial compartmental extension: build a simple compartmental model along an axonal arbor (soma, proximal/distal terminal clusters) with local D_i and R_i variables and inter-compartment diffusion of reactive lipid species and local ATP coupling. Use published arbor reconstructions to parameterize compartment sizes and varicosity concentrations. Study how spatial clustering of terminals (hotspots) changes local collapse nucleation and whole-cell vulnerability.

6) Sensitivity and uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol or Morris) across assembled priors to rank which biological rates (DA oxidation rate, LP chain-propagation exponent, GPx/GSH capacity, PLA2/ACSL/LPCAT turnover, ATP cost of repair) most shift the bifurcation location and collapse probability. Identify which experimental measurements would most reduce predictive uncertainty.

7) In silico intervention tests: simulate candidate interventions with literature-derived effect sizes: (a) boosting GSH (e.g., N-acetylcysteine-like increase in pool), (b) enhancing GPx activity, (c) upregulating acyltransferase/repair enzyme expression, (d) modestly reducing firing rate or release probability, and (e) combined multi-target strategies. Quantify required percent-changes to (i) prevent tipping across a lifespan, (ii) reduce collapse probability by target fractions, and (iii) rescue after collapse (hysteresis thresholds).

8) Mapping to published observations and biomarkers: compare predicted membrane-damage trajectories and thresholds with published biochemical/pathological markers (lipid peroxidation products, 4-HNE, malondialdehyde levels, oxidized phospholipid histology) in SNc vs VTA and age/PD cohorts. Propose practical biomarker thresholds (e.g., oxidized phospholipid concentration) that indicate proximity to the tipping point.

9) Code, data, and reproducibility: publish all curated priors, model code (Python; NumPy/SciPy, pyDSTool/AUTO notebooks, stochastic simulation scripts), parameter-uncertainty notebooks, and visualization dashboards for researchers to map new biochemical or anatomical measurements onto the membrane-repair tipping phase space.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Parameter uncertainty and biochemical complexity: detailed, in vivo kinetic measurements of lipid-peroxidation chain propagation rates, enzymatic turnover in adult SNc neurons, and extracellular oxidation rates are limited. Mitigation: use broad priors from in vitro and ex vivo studies, perform extensive sensitivity and uncertainty analyses, and emphasize robust qualitative conclusions (existence of bistability, relative SNc vs VTA mapping) rather than precise numeric thresholds.

2) Simplifying chemistry and biology: the model condenses complex lipid species, multiple antioxidant systems (vitamin E, CoQ, GPx), iron-catalyzed Fenton chemistry, and repair pathways into simplified kinetics. While necessary for a tractable topological analysis, this abstraction may omit modulatory effects. We will test multiple kinetic kernels (different cooperativity degrees, explicit iron-catalysis terms) to check robustness.

3) Mapping damage to neuronal death: membrane damage is a plausible proximate cause of dysfunction, but linking D(t) directly to irreversible cell death is an abstraction. We will treat 'collapse' as entry into a pathological attractor characterized by sustained high membrane damage and severely reduced energetic reserve; empirical validation would require experimental correlation between predicted biomarkers and functional loss.

4) Data comparability across species/tissues: many quantitative biochemical measures originate from non-human or non-midbrain tissues; cross-species extrapolation is required. We will explicitly propagate cross-species scaling uncertainties and recommend which targeted measurements (e.g., SNc GSH pools, oxidized phospholipid staining) would most reduce uncertainty.

5) Overlap with other mechanisms: membrane repair tipping likely interacts with mitochondrial, proteostatic, and glial mechanisms explored in other proposals. This project isolates membrane repair to test sufficiency and identify discriminative predictions (e.g., rescue by acyltransferase upregulation vs mitochondrial-targeted interventions). Positive results would motivate integrated multi-mechanism modeling.

6) Computational cost for spatial stochastic simulations: compartmental spatial stochastic simulations across realistic arbors and long simulated lifespans may be computationally demanding. We'll use adaptive hybrid methods (tau-leaping, moment-closure approximations) and focus high-resolution simulations on critical parameter regimes identified by coarse scans.

7) Translational interpretation: predicted intervention magnitudes (e.g., fold-increase in repair enzyme activity required to rescue post-collapse) may be difficult to achieve clinically. Still, quantifying these magnitudes provides actionable guidance on which molecular targets are realistic and which require combined strategies.

Name: epigenetic_lockin_tipping
Title: Epigenetic Lock‑In: Chromatin-Mediated Irreversible Tipping of Neuronal Energetics in Parkinsons Disease
Short Hypothesis: A slow, self-reinforcing epigenetic feedback — activity- and metabolism-dependent chromatin remodeling that downregulates mitochondrial maintenance programs — converts transient energetic stress into a long-lived transcriptional 'lock-in' that produces a saddle-node bistability and practical irreversibility in vulnerable SNc neurons. This mechanism is distinct from purely metabolic or proteostatic tipping because the slow chromatin state acts as a dynamical memory that amplifies small energetic deficits into persistent loss of mitochondrial recovery capacity. The hypothesis is best addressed by integrating published epigenetic, single-cell transcriptomic, and metabolic summary data into a minimal dynamical model (mitochondrial capacity M, energetic reserve E, chromatin activation H) and testing whether literature-derived parameter ensembles place SNc but not VTA neurons inside a bistable band where transcriptional lock-in enables stochastic escape and hysteresis.
Related Work: Prior modeling has explained selective SNc vulnerability via axonal load, mitochondrial bistability, proteostatic allocation, mtDNA dynamics, glial buffering, or NAD+ redox decline. Empirical studies document activity- and metabolism-sensitive chromatin regulation (acetyl-CoA and NAD+-dependent histone modifications), age- and PD-associated changes in transcription of mitochondrial/mitophagy genes, and single-cell RNA-seq/ATAC-seq datasets from midbrain cell types showing differential regulation. However, existing tipping models either treat gene regulation as a static parameter (e.g., lower biogenesis rates) or focus on metabolic variables alone (e.g., NAD+). This proposal differs by making a compact, slow epigenetic state H the explicit dynamical variable that (i) controls expression of mitochondrial maintenance programs cooperatively, (ii) is modulated by cellular energetic/metabolic signals (acetyl-CoA, NAD+, ROS, calcium), and (iii) exhibits self-reinforcement (histone modification maintenance, chromatin compaction), thus producing topological bistability and hysteresis. This is not a trivial extension: including a slow transcriptional memory changes the geometry of basins, timing of prodrome-to-collapse transitions, and intervention windows (early epigenetic reprogramming vs late metabolic rescue).
Abstract: Selective loss of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons in Parkinsons disease contrasts with sparing of ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons. Energetic load, calcium stress, mitochondrial dysfunction, proteostatic failure, and NAD+ decline have all been implicated, yet none fully explains why brief insults can lead to long-lived, effectively irreversible cellular collapse. We propose an epigenetic-lock-in tipping hypothesis: activity- and metabolism-sensitive chromatin modifications (histone acetylation/methylation, chromatin accessibility) constitute a slow, self-reinforcing variable H that governs the transcription of mitochondrial biogenesis/quality-control genes. Transient energetic deficits reduce acetyl-CoA/NAD+-dependent chromatin activation, lowering expression of maintenance programs and degrading mitochondrial capacity M; because H is maintained on long timescales (epigenetic memory), reduced H further impairs recovery, producing positive feedback. A minimal three-variable dynamical model (M: mitochondrial functional mass; E: fast energetic reserve; H: chromatin activation) parameterized from published metabolic, epigenetic, and single-cell transcriptomic/ATAC-seq summary statistics generically exhibits a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation: SNc-like parameter ensembles map into a bistable band where a healthy high-M/high-H attractor coexists with a collapsed low-M/low-H attractor. Stochastic simulations show physiologically plausible noise and transient insults can drive SNc trajectories across the separatrix; hysteresis makes post-collapse metabolic rescue ineffective unless chromatin state is reprogrammed beyond realistic limits. We will calibrate model priors using published assays (histone mark changes with age/activity, expression of PGC-1a and mitophagy genes, acetyl-CoA/NAD+ proxies), perform bifurcation and sensitivity analyses, and produce falsifiable predictions about timing and magnitude of epigenetic-targeted interventions (HDAC inhibition, acetyl-CoA boosting) needed to avert or reverse collapse. All code and curated parameter ensembles will be released to enable empirical testing and mapping of new datasets onto the epigenetic distance-to-tipping metric.
Experiments: 1) Literature curation and priors: assemble quantitative published summaries for (a) activity/metabolism-dependent chromatin marks (H3K27ac, H3K9ac abundance changes with activity, acetyl-CoA/NAD+ coupling), (b) age- and PD-associated transcriptomic changes in mitochondrial biogenesis/mitophagy (PGC-1a, TFAM, Parkin/PINK1) from single-cell/nucleus RNA-seq and bulk studies comparing SNc vs VTA, (c) dynamics/timescales of histone mark maintenance and reversal (HDAC/HAT kinetics), and (d) metabolic variables (NAD+/NADH, acetyl-CoA proxies, ATP consumption estimates) and their scaling with axonal load and firing. Build probabilistic priors for model parameters from these sources and document citation mapping.

2) Minimal dynamical model: implement a compact three-variable ODE model: dE/dt = production(M) - consumption(Demand(A,C)) - coupling_loss_to_H_changes; dM/dt = biogenesis(H,E) - damage(Demand,ROS)*M; dH/dt = f(H,E,M,activity) where biogenesis depends cooperatively on H (e.g., Hill function) and H evolves slowly via acetylation/deacetylation kinetics modulated by energy/redox signals. Choose minimal nonlinear forms that permit saddle-node bifurcations and map parameters to literature priors for interpretability.

3) Deterministic bifurcation analysis: use numerical continuation (AUTO/pyDSTool/MatCont) to locate saddle-node folds and compute bistable bands in control-parameter planes (effective load combining axonal A and calcium C, baseline chromatin activation capacity, and epigenetic maintenance timescale). Compute separatrix geometry and hysteresis width, and identify critical parameter regimes where small reductions in H shift system across the fold.

4) Mapping cell types using single-cell datasets: using published single-cell/nucleus RNA-seq and ATAC-seq atlases of midbrain neurons, compute cell-type/module scores for (i) mitochondrial/mitophagy gene expression, (ii) chromatin modifier enzyme expression (HATs, HDACs, sirtuins), and (iii) activity proxies (ion-channel expression, pacemaking-related genes). Use these scores plus morphological summaries (from literature) to construct SNc- and VTA-like parameter ensembles (with uncertainty) that map into model axes (A, baseline H capacity, biogenesis responsiveness). Evaluate where empirical ensembles fall relative to bifurcation boundaries.

5) Stochastic ensemble simulations and first-passage analysis: add physiologically plausible noise (episodic oxidative insults, transient sleep/behavioral changes) and run Monte Carlo simulations for SNc- and VTA-like ensembles. Compute collapse probability and distribution of first-passage times, sensitivity to H maintenance timescale, and how early transient H perturbations alter lifetime risk. Metrics: probability of collapse by modeled age, median time-to-collapse, and hazard ratios comparing SNc vs VTA ensembles.

6) Sensitivity and uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) across priors to rank which parameters (H maintenance rate, cooperativity of H -> biogenesis, NAD+/acetyl-CoA coupling strength, axonal load) most affect bistability and collapse risk. Use resulting ranking to identify most informative experimental measurements and promising intervention levers.

7) In silico intervention tests: simulate epigenetic-targeted interventions (increase H via HDAC inhibition or HAT activation modeled as increasing H synthesis rate or decreasing deacetylation rate) and metabolic co-interventions (acetyl-CoA precursors, NAD+ boosters). Quantify minimal effect sizes and timing windows required to (a) prevent tipping across a lifespan ensemble and (b) reverse collapse when applied post-collapse, accounting for hysteresis. Compare required effect sizes to reported pharmacological effect ranges in the literature.

8) Robustness checks and model variants: test alternate mechanistic couplings (H driven by NAD+ vs acetyl-CoA, inclusion of chromatin accessibility as separate fast/slow variable, explicit transcriptional delays) to ensure main topological conclusions (existence of epigenetic-driven bistability and altered intervention windows) are robust.

9) Release code, priors, and mapping tools: publish all curated datasets, model code (Python notebooks), and an interactive mapping utility allowing researchers to input cell-type module scores to obtain a probabilistic distance-to-epigenetic-tipping estimate.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data gaps on cell-type-resolved metabolite and chromatin dynamics: direct measurements of acetyl-CoA and NAD+ pools and histone modification timescales in adult human SNc vs VTA neurons are sparse. Mitigation: use proxy measurements (enzyme expression, bulk metabolomics), broad priors, hierarchical Bayesian propagation of uncertainty, and sensitivity analyses to identify which missing measurements most constrain conclusions.

2) Simplification of epigenetic biology: chromatin regulation involves many marks, readers/writers, three-dimensional genome architecture, and cell-cycle/repair coupling. Our minimal H variable abstracts this complexity to capture slow transcriptional memory; while necessary for tractability, some molecular nuances may shift quantitative thresholds. We will test multiple plausible kernels (different cooperativity and maintenance dynamics) to ensure qualitative robustness.

3) Mapping expression modules to dynamical parameters: inferring mechanistic parameter values (e.g., baseline H capacity) from gene-expression/ATAC proxies is indirect and uncertain. We will propagate mapping uncertainty explicitly and emphasize topological (existence of bistability, hysteresis) and relative (SNc vs VTA) findings rather than exact numeric thresholds.

4) Interactions with other mechanisms: epigenetic lock-in likely interacts with NAD+/redox, proteostasis, mtDNA dynamics, and glial support explored in other proposals. This project isolates epigenetic feedback to test sufficiency; positive results would motivate integrated multi-mechanism modeling in follow-up work.

5) Predictive translation limitations: while the model can predict required effect sizes for epigenetic or metabolic interventions, translating pharmacological doses from reported molecular effect sizes to in vivo neuronal chromatin shifts is complex. We will carefully compare modeled effect sizes to reported molecular changes (e.g., fold-change in H3K27ac after HDAC inhibitors) and report uncertainties, not clinical prescriptions.

6) Possible negative outcome: if literature priors cannot produce epigenetic-driven folds under any plausible parameterization, the result still constrains hypotheses and identifies critical measurements (e.g., histone-modification lifetimes or acetyl-CoA coupling strengths) required to validate or falsify the epigenetic lock-in idea.

Name: spike_train_early_warning
Title: Early-warning signals in spike trains: detecting imminent energetic tipping in vulnerable dopaminergic neurons
Short Hypothesis: Slow energetic decline (mitochondrial/repair capacity) brings SNc dopaminergic neurons close to a saddle-node tipping point that produces critical slowing and other predictable changes in fast-timescale spike-train statistics (variance, autocorrelation, ISI-skew, spectral slope). These statistical early-warning signals are detectable in published in vivo and ex vivo electrophysiology datasets (SNc vs VTA, aging and PD models) and can be combined with a minimal two-timescale dynamical model to (i) infer proximity to tipping for populations and (ii) generate falsifiable biomarkers for preclinical intervention. This approach is best addressed computationally by re-analyzing published spike-train data and linking observed statistical changes to a literature-parameterized energetic model rather than by new wet-lab experiments.
Related Work: Prior PD vulnerability models focus on cellular energetics, axonal arbor load, proteostatic limits, mitochondrial network dynamics, and topological bifurcations producing bistability and hysteresis. Separately, neuroscience literature on early-warning signals of critical transitions (critical slowing down) demonstrates that approaching bifurcations produces increased variance and autocorrelation in observables; some work has applied these ideas to population neural signals (LFP/EEG) and network states but not systematically to single-unit spike trains tied to cellular energetic tipping. Existing SNc vs VTA studies document differing firing patterns, pacemaking variability, and age- or toxin-induced changes in electrophysiology (Surmeier lab, others), and some papers provide publicly accessible spike-train data (or link repositories). What is new here is (i) combining a minimal, literature-anchored, two-timescale energetic-spiking model that predicts precise changes in spike-train statistics as a neuron approaches an energetic saddle-node fold, (ii) systematically re-analyzing published single-unit spike-train datasets (SNc vs VTA, aging cohorts and PD models) for early-warning markers, and (iii) using Bayesian/likelihood frameworks to map observed spike statistics to a probabilistic distance-to-tipping metric. This differs from past models because it (a) makes directly testable, data-grounded predictions about observable electrophysiological biomarkers, (b) uses only published datasets and modeling, and (c) yields practical early-detection tools experimentalists can apply without new invasive assays.
Abstract: Parkinson's disease features a long prodromal phase followed by relatively rapid loss of substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) dopaminergic neurons. Theoretical work suggests that nonlinear energetic feedbacks (mitochondrial cooperative recovery, proteostatic allocation) can create saddle-node bifurcations and bistability, explaining irreversibility and selective vulnerability. Dynamical systems theory predicts that approaching such bifurcations produces critical slowing down and characteristic changes in fast-timescale observables. We propose to (i) derive quantitative predictions from a compact two-timescale model that couples fast spike generation to a slow energetic reserve variable and (ii) test those predictions by re-analyzing published single-unit spike-train datasets from SNc and VTA neurons across aging and PD-model studies. The model shows that as the slow energetic variable drifts toward a fold, spike trains should exhibit increased variance, rising autocorrelation (lag-1), heavier-tailed interspike interval distributions (increased skew/kurtosis), elevated low-frequency power (flattened spectral slope), and longer recovery times from perturbations. We will compile and harmonize published electrophysiology datasets (in vivo anesthetized/awake recordings, ex vivo slices, genetic/toxin models, age series) and compute a battery of time-series early-warning statistics in sliding windows. Using approximate-likelihood and Bayesian inversion, we will map observed statistics onto model-derived distance-to-tipping posteriors and compare SNc vs VTA distributions and age-/model-dependent trends. We will also simulate realistic noise and heterogeneity ensembles to compute expected false-positive/false-negative rates and propose robust detection thresholds. This purely computational program leverages literature parameter ranges and publicly available data to produce falsifiable electrophysiological biomarkers of imminent cellular energetic tipping, prioritize which spike metrics are most predictive, and quantify how large and how early interventions must be to avert collapse.
Experiments: 1) Model development and analytic predictions: construct a minimal two-timescale model coupling fast spiking dynamics r(t) (e.g., stochastic leaky integrate-and-fire or reduced firing-rate dynamics with adaptation) to a slow energetic reserve E(t) (mitochondrial functional capacity/ATP reserve) parameterized from the literature. Choose forms so nondimensionalized control parameter (effective load L = f(A,C,...) / biogenesis_capacity) produces a saddle-node fold in the (E,r) reduced dynamics. Perform bifurcation continuation (pyDSTool/AUTO) to locate the fold and analytically/numerically derive how key spike-train statistics (variance, lag-1 autocorrelation, recovery time, ISI-skew, Fano factor over windows, power spectral slope at low frequencies) change as a function of distance-to-fold. Produce explicit mapping functions or lookup tables from model parameterization to expected statistical shifts under physiologically plausible noise.

2) Literature-driven parameterization: assemble published estimates for fast-timescale spiking (baseline firing rates, pacemaking variability), calcium-related energetic cost per spike, mitochondrial turnover/biogenesis rates, and typical noise amplitudes for SNc and VTA neurons from electrophysiology and mitochondrial/energetic studies (e.g., Surmeier lab, Pissadaki & Bolam). Build probabilistic priors for parameters, derive ensembles of model trajectories, and compute expected ranges of statistical early-warning signatures for SNc vs VTA ensembles.

3) Data discovery and assembly: search and curate published single-unit spike-train datasets and digitized spike-time series available from papers or linked repositories: candidate sources include aging studies and PD-model electrophysiology (e.g., rotenone/MPTP models), in vivo SNc/VTA recordings, and ex vivo slice pacemaking recordings. Document metadata (species, anesthetized/awake, age, experimental perturbations) and harmonize sampling/resolution and unit-identification conventions. If data are not directly downloadable, extract digitized spike-trains from published supplement files or through links in papers (Semantic Scholar references will guide discovery).

4) Time-series feature computation: for each spike train, compute windowed statistics in sliding windows (e.g., 30s to 5min windows depending on recording length): mean firing rate, variance, Fano factor, lag-1 autocorrelation of firing-rate time series, ISI distribution moments (skewness, kurtosis), power spectral density slope in low-frequency band (1-10 Hz), and recovery time after spontaneous or evoked perturbations if available. Compute confidence intervals via bootstrapping and estimate trends vs time/age per neuron where longitudinal data exist. Also compute surrogate-control metrics (e.g., phase-randomized surrogates) to calibrate expected statistic variance under null.

5) Model-to-data inversion and distance-to-tipping estimation: using model-derived mapping functions and priors, implement Bayesian inversion (approximate likelihood or ABC-SMC if likelihood intractable) to infer a posterior over distance-to-fold for each recorded neuron or recording session from its measured statistics. Account for measurement noise, recording length, and potential state confounds (anesthesia). Produce posterior distributions of distance-to-tipping and compare SNc vs VTA populations, age groups, and disease models.

6) Validation with synthetic data and power analysis: generate synthetic spike-train datasets from the full stochastic two-timescale model under known distances-to-fold and noise levels to validate inversion pipeline, compute sensitivity/specificity curves, ROC analysis for chosen statistic combinations, and estimate minimum recording durations needed to detect early-warning signals with acceptable false-positive rates.

7) Population-level analyses & hypothesis testing: test hypotheses: (a) SNc neurons show statistically significant shifts toward predicted early-warning signatures compared to VTA in aging cohorts and PD models; (b) early-warning statistics correlate across neurons recorded in same animals/regions (shared slow driver); (c) computed posterior distance-to-tipping predicts reported vulnerability markers (e.g., molecular stress markers reported in same study). Use hierarchical Bayesian models to pool evidence across studies while accounting for study-level confounds.

8) Predictive guidance & experimental recommendations: quantify how large and how early interventions (e.g., reducing firing by x%, boosting mitochondrial biogenesis by y%) must be, given model uncertainty, to shift posterior distance-to-tipping by a target margin. Publish recommended spike-train metrics and recording lengths for experimentalists to use as practical preclinical biomarkers of imminent collapse.

9) Reproducible release: publish all curated spike-train datasets (where permissable), analysis code, model code, inversion notebooks, and a user-friendly calculator mapping measured spike statistics into distance-to-tipping posteriors.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data availability and heterogeneity: high-quality, long-duration single-unit recordings from identified SNc and VTA neurons across aging or PD-model time courses may be limited or heterogeneous (anesthesia, species differences, recording conditions). Mitigation: exhaustively curate published datasets, harmonize metadata, use hierarchical models to account for study effects, and present sensitivity analyses showing which dataset features most affect inference.

2) Mapping model variables to observables: the link between latent energetic reserve and spike-train statistics depends on model form and parameters; different plausible models might predict different magnitudes of statistical change. Mitigation: use an ensemble of mechanistic variants, propagate parameter uncertainty, emphasize robust qualitative signatures (e.g., rising autocorrelation and variance) and provide credible intervals for predictions.

3) Confounding state changes: observed increases in variance/autocorrelation could arise from shifts in neuromodulatory state, anesthesia level, or behavioral context rather than energetic tipping. Mitigation: exploit within-study controls, compare SNc vs VTA recorded under identical conditions, use surrogate controls and state markers where available, and report limits on causal claims.

4) False positives and specificity: critical-slowing-like signatures can appear before many types of transitions; demonstrating that observed signals specifically reflect energetic tipping requires careful cross-validation. Mitigation: test multiple complementary statistics, use model inversion to estimate distance-to-fold rather than relying on single metrics, and validate on synthetic data to quantify false-positive rates.

5) Temporal resolution and recording length: detecting early-warning statistics reliably may require long continuous recordings that many published datasets lack. Mitigation: include power analyses to determine minimum required durations and recommend experimental protocols; where necessary, pool across neurons recorded simultaneously to boost effective sample size for shared slow drivers.

6) Translational step to humans: available human single-unit data are rare. The project focuses on animal data and model-based translation to suggest biomarkers for preclinical studies; extension to human noninvasive signals (EEG/MEG/LFP) would require additional modeling linking single-unit signatures to population signals for clinical use.

7) Model misspecification risks: if the true dominant tipping mechanism does not couple strongly to spiking (e.g., purely axonal terminal failures far from soma), spike-train early-warning signals may be weak or absent. A null result is informative: it constrains which cellular mechanisms are detectable at the electrophysiological level and guides where to look next (terminals, imaging biomarkers).

Title: Collective pacemaking: synchrony-driven energetic tipping in SNc dopaminergic networks
Short Hypothesis: Transient emergence of population-level synchrony among nigral pacemaking neurons (via electrical coupling, ephaptic interactions, or shared synaptic/volume-transmission input) transiently synchronizes calcium influx and release-driven ATP demand across many cells. This collective spike-time alignment can push an otherwise-subthreshold ensemble of neurons into a correlated, high-demand episode that triggers a network-amplified saddle-node energetic collapse; VTA populations, being less tightly coupled or less densely packed, avoid this collective tipping. Published reports of intermittent SNc synchrony, gap-junction/field-coupling markers, and electrophysiological coherence metrics suffice to parameterize and falsify this mechanism computationally without new wet-lab data.
Related Work: Existing PD vulnerability theories emphasize single-cell energetic load (axon arbor size, calcium pacemaking), mitochondrial bistability, proteostatic limits, arbor topology/percolation, astrocytic buffering, and temporal transport�91demand resonance. Several proposed models address population-level effects via shared astrocytic/metabolic pools, but none focus on neuronal electrical/field coupling as the driver of synchronous, network-scale demand surges that transiently amplify per-cell load and generate collective bifurcation geometry. Separately, electrophysiology literature reports episodes of correlated firing and altered coherence in midbrain dopaminergic populations (in vivo and slice), and molecular studies report expression of connexins and other coupling mediators in midbrain neurons. This proposal differs by (i) treating synchrony as a dynamical, emergent control parameter that can create a collective saddle-node-like fold absent at single-cell level, (ii) integrating published coupling/coherence statistics and anatomical density metrics to ground coupling strengths and encounter probabilities, and (iii) combining mean-field bifurcation analysis with network-level stochastic simulations and re-analysis of published spike-train datasets to test whether synchrony precedes energetic failure signatures. It is not a trivial extension of prior temporal-resonance or astrocyte-community models because electrical/field coupling produces rapid, transient global alignment of fast demand events across many cells and thereby changes the topology (width and depth of basins, hysteresis) of the aggregate system.
Abstract: Dopaminergic neurons of the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc) are lost preferentially in Parkinson's disease while ventral tegmental area (VTA) neurons are comparatively resistant. Most mechanistic accounts focus on cell-autonomous factors (axonal load, calcium pacemaking, mitochondrial fragility) or shared metabolic buffering (astrocytes). We propose an orthogonal, computationally testable mechanism: emergent network synchrony among SNc pacemaking neurons transiently aligns calcium entry and release-driven ATP consumption across many cells, producing collective high-demand episodes that push the ensemble past a load-induced saddle-node bifurcation into a collapsed energetic state. Key features: (i) coupling modalities (electrical gap junctions, ephaptic interactions in dense terminal fields, correlated volume-transmission input) are parameterized from published expression and electrophysiology studies; (ii) each neuron carries a slow mitochondrial/energetic state variable that integrates demand and recovers nonlinearly, allowing single-cell bistability in marginal cases; (iii) fast-timescale synchrony raises effective instantaneous demand multiplicatively across the network, creating a genuinely collective fold that appears at network scale even when isolated neurons would be safe. We will assemble literature priors for coupling strengths, coherence statistics, firing/burst distributions, and anatomical density, then analyze a family of coupled stochastic pacemaker-energetic models using mean-field reductions, bifurcation continuation, and large-scale stochastic simulation on anatomically-informed network graphs. We will re-analyze publicly available midbrain spike-train datasets to test whether transient increases in synchrony correlate with signatures of critical slowing or later pathology markers. The model predicts specific falsifiable signatures: (a) synchronized episodes that precede collapse, (b) a non-linear dependence of collapse probability on coupling strength and network size, and (c) higher leverage of desynchronizing interventions (gap-junction blockers, mild decorrelation of inputs) than equivalent reductions in single-cell demand. All code and curated priors will be released to enable experimental mapping of synchrony-based distance-to-tipping metrics.
Experiments: 1) Literature assembly and parameter priors: systematically curate published data on (a) electrophysiological coherence and pairwise spike-time correlations for SNc and VTA neurons (in vivo and ex vivo), (b) expression and localization of gap-junction proteins (connexins) and other coupling mediators in midbrain dopaminergic neurons, (c) anatomical density/packing metrics for SNc vs VTA (somatic density, local neuropil/varicosity density), and (d) single-cell pacemaking statistics (baseline firing rate, ISI CV, burst probability) and per-spike energetic cost (calcium handling + vesicle recycling). Build probabilistic priors (distributions) for coupling strengths, network degree, and demand parameters with citation provenance.

2) Minimal network model formulation: build an explicit, mechanistic stochastic network model where each neuron i has fast spiking dynamics (stochastic pacemaker with adjustable burstiness and refractory properties) coupled to a slow energetic variable E_i(t) (mitochondrial functional reserve) with nonlinear recovery (cooperative biogenesis) and damage proportional to instantaneous calcium/release demand. Coupling modalities: (a) direct electrical coupling modeled as linear phase/potential coupling (strength g_ij), (b) ephaptic/volume-transmission coupling modeled as neuron-density-dependent field coupling (global or distance-weighted), and (c) correlated external input modeled via shared drive processes with tunable correlation coefficient. Instantaneous consumption in each neuron scales with local spike events and with a synchrony amplification factor that models coincident energy-demand overlap (e.g., simultaneous spikes cause transient local extracellular ionic recycling costs that scale supra-linearly). Implement in Python with efficient event-driven simulation (Gillespie-like for fast events plus ODE update for slow variables).

3) Mean-field reduction & bifurcation continuation: derive a reduced mean-field description (population-averaged E and synchrony order parameter S) to study how coupling and network size produce collective folds. Use numerical continuation (pyDSTool/AUTO) to locate saddle-node folds in the (effective load, coupling strength) plane, compute hysteresis width, and obtain separatrix geometry. Demonstrate regimes where network-level bistability exists though isolated neurons (g_ij=0) are monostable.

4) Stochastic network simulations on anatomically informed graphs: sample network topologies (random geometric, small-world, and empirically informed adjacency based on packing density priors) and run ensembles of stochastic simulations across the posterior priors for coupling and demand. Track observables: population synchrony index (Kuramoto-like or spike-train coherence), fraction of neurons collapsed (E_i below threshold), time-to-collapse distribution, and spatial clustering of failure. Evaluate how collapse probability scales with mean coupling, network size, and synchrony amplification exponent.

5) Re-analysis of published spike-train datasets: locate and download public SNc/VTA single-unit datasets (or digitize spike-time data from supplements) and compute time-resolved synchrony/coherence measures (sliding-window pairwise correlations, population synchrony index). Test whether transient increases in synchrony are followed by changes in slow electrophysiological markers (e.g., ISI variance), molecular stress proxies reported in the same studies, or are more prevalent in disease-model recordings. Use permutation tests and generalized linear mixed models to control for confounds (anesthesia, behavioral state).

6) Sensitivity & uncertainty quantification: perform global sensitivity analysis (Sobol/Morris) across uncertain priors to rank which biological quantities (gap-junction coupling g, ephaptic strength, shared-input correlation, per-spike energy cost, cooperativity in recovery) most affect network-level bifurcation location and collapse probability. Identify robust intervention targets under prior uncertainty.

7) In silico intervention experiments: simulate interventions including (a) reducing coupling (gap-junction blockade) across ranges informed by pharmacology literature, (b) desynchronizing inputs (adding uncorrelated noise to shared drive), and (c) modest reductions in per-spike cost (simulate L-type calcium channel partial blockade). Quantify required effect sizes to reduce collapse probability by 50% and compare intervention leverage per unit molecular/physiological change.

8) Predictive signatures and experimental recommendations: derive specific, testable early-warning signatures (e.g., thresholded increases in pairwise coherence or population phase-locking that raise collapse hazard by X-fold). Publish code, analysis pipelines, and a mapping tool that allows experimentalists to input measured coherence/coupling estimates to obtain a probabilistic network-distance-to-tipping metric.
Risk Factors and Limitations: 1) Data gaps for coupling translation: molecular expression of connexins or other coupling mediators does not directly map to effective electrical/ephaptic coupling strength in vivo. Mitigation: use broad priors, sensitivity analysis, and multiple coupling model forms (electrical, ephaptic, shared-input) to show robustness of qualitative conclusions across plausible coupling realizations.

2) Heterogeneous recording conditions: published spike-train datasets vary in anesthesia, behavioral state, and species which can confound synchrony metrics. Mitigation: careful metadata curation, within-study contrasts (SNc vs VTA where available), hierarchical statistical models, and surrogate controls to bound inference.

3) Mechanistic ambiguity: synchrony may be a correlate rather than a driver of pathology (e.g., both could be driven by a third factor). This computational program seeks to test sufficiency and plausibility, not to claim causality from existing cross-sectional data. We will propose falsifiable predictions (interventions that desynchronize should lower collapse probability in silico) to guide experimental tests.

4) Model abstraction: the synchrony amplification function (how coincident spikes supra-linearly increase effective ATP cost) is a modeling choice with uncertain exponent/shape. Mitigation: explore families of amplification kernels (linear, sub/superlinear, saturating) and show which qualitative results persist.

5) Translation to human PD: even if synchrony-driven tipping is mechanistically plausible, its relative contribution to human PD pathogenesis alongside proteostatic, mitochondrial, and glial mechanisms may be modest. The goal is to establish plausibility bounds and generate discriminative experimental signatures to evaluate the mechanism empirically.

6) Computational cost: large ensembles of stochastic network simulations with many neurons and long simulated lifespans can be demanding. We'll use mean-field guidance to focus high-resolution simulations on critical parameter regimes and employ efficient event-driven implementations and parallelization compatible with standard lab computational resources.
